Gaffigan is one of the most reliably hilarious comedians out there. He has several specials out and this is as good as any of them.He also works clean. It's nice to be able to show my kids a comedian without being worried about content.

Normally this guy has me in stitches. I've been a fan for years. I saw him live a few years ago and he was amazing. But this one just feels lazy to me. Don't get me wrong, some of it is pretty good... but for every good moment there seems to be several moments of sub par (compared to his normal genius) filler. My buddy put it perfect - a lot of dad-joke quality material here.

I've been a long time fan. This guy is my go to comedian and his comedy is always clean and crisp. I've listened to his prior sets repeatedly, especially on long drives. But his set just seems less enjoyable. It's fine, it has its funny sections, but it just didn't have me in giggles constantly like his prior works had and still have. So yeah, check it out, but maybe after you're done with all of his prior work.
I laughed so hard I had an asthma attack! Well done Jim!

He's got good timing and wit, and made me laugh a few times. Yeah, it sounds like a laugh track, but I doubt it.The guy makes fun of Irish people who mispronounce Billy Joel's name, and then mispronounces Anne Frank's name a few minutes later.
The canned laughter made this show unwatchable, it was all I could hear. Was the audience so unreceptive it needed a laugh track like a sitcom.

I love his comedy. Clean and funny. This one though was unwatchable because of obviously engineered laughs. Just painful. I wish Jim, his brain tumor surviving wife and 16 children well, but dude, you can kill without the awful laugh track. Jim Gaffigan, Quality Time may be very funny and enjoyable.
Not much to say except Jim Gaffigan is as funny as he's ever been, with all new material. Constant laughs, laid back, great time.

Nothing much to say. As many other users pointed out, the laugh track is unbearable and very obvious. The guy says "hi" and you hear the same laughs we've been hearing since the 60s in every sitcom. Quite pathetic. His humor is not great. It could have been entertaining anyway and somewhat enjoyable, but the constant fake laughter makes it impossible to watch.

This was the third show I watched from Bert Kreischer. After The Machine (2016) and Secret Time (2018) I had high hopes for this new show but even if I still had a lot of fun watching Hey Big Boy i have to admit his other shows were slightly better. He's still very funny though, certainly when he tells the stories with his kids Georgia and Ila. The ones with Ila are the funniest in my opinion. He's still performing shirtless, nice signature by the way, his jokes are still funny because of the way he tells and mimics them. You can't fault his stage presence, it's hilarious and adds to the comedy. Bert Kreischer is one of my favorite stand-up comedians, can't wait for his next performance.
This one is mediocre and I think he needs to take a break because he's gasping for jokes right now. Maybe its how the mic'd the theater but you can't hear the crowd engagement that much.

Turned off in the first 10 mins cause it just wasn't my thing. I'm sure other people like his comedy though. The joke about him being excited when black people recognize him was super cringey. That made me turn it off. And I can just hear yall saying, "it's comedy for a reason, he doesn't actually mean it". And I totally agree. And I'm aware it's just all subjective. I know Burt is a good dude. Watch for yourself to make your own judgment
The first half of the show was pretty funny, but after that it started feeling a little boring, with very minimal laughable moments

This was very funny, I watched it in 2 halves and checked out half of Mark Maron's between. Bert's was a lot funnier for me, He's loveable and engaging and the humour is very relatable. I see Tom has a new special coming next week, see how that measures up. Tom is so fat.
Wow. One of the best specials Netflix has ever put out. Congrats Bert.

I am a Huge Bert Kreischer and love his previous stand ups and his podcasts and most of his material. But this was definitely his not material by a far stretch. I was very disappointed and I'm sure he put his heart into like everything else but this one just missed the mark. Dont get me wrong it definitely had its funny parts but overall I just wasnt crazy and felt forced! Sorry to say but it is what it is. Heres to the next one Bert! 🍻

This is as good, if not better than 'Secret Time!' This special is hilarious and shows Bert is one of the best stand ups going around. He certainly tells a story better than anyone. I watched this by myself and was laughing out loud constantly!
As Bert continuously gets better at his craft, he moves away from being a partying story teller and you realize just how good of a comic he is.
Great jokes & stories, no time wasted, but directing was a bit off, especially with Bert looking straight at the camera at times which made it super-weird, apart from that great work.

Bert has fallen out of touch with his core audience, he's aging and it isn't doing any good for his comedy. I'm a big fan that loves two bears one cave with Tom, and I love seeing Bert as a guest on podcasts but his stand-up routine is unrelatable to his core audience and this sadly missed the target.
DO NOT WATCH WHILE EATING OR DRINKING. You will choke! my belly got quite the work out from laughing so hard.
The bast moment in this special is when he finds out that world wouldn't be great if Germany won WW2. Nazi Germany lost WW2. Deal with that Bert!
Let down. Been a fan of his for a long time. Have made the trip to see him in Atlanta. That being said i can be real about it and it wasn't his best content. It mediocre at best.
If you have a sense of humor that's the most I laughed in a long time watching stand up. I was even sober for it and had tears running down my face! Excellent job can't wait for more
I wanted to like this so much. I'm a fan of his other specials and his podcast work but just didn't enjoy this special.
Bert is one of my favorite podcast comedians, but his stand up isn't my favorite. This special has some great moments that I laughed really hard, but some of the stuff wasn't exactly my taste.

The material that Eddie Griffin delivers in Eddie Griffin: Undeniable is some of the most racist, sexually abusive, insulting, angriest and disrespectful material a comedian could deliver in 2018. The humor is funny, thought provoking, serious and silly. Eddie Griffin: Undeniable is intended to be equally offensive to everyone and is well balanced as to not offend any particular group before moving on to offend another. Be prepared, as Eddie Griffin: Undeniable will come out of the gate and go straight for the jugular, but hang around for the entire show as the majority of viewers shall be entertained. Eddie Griffin: Undeniable is reflection of a current global society that will continue it's ways long after we are gone, but...Eddie Griffin really needs to work on his impressions.
All the low rating comes from whoever he offended in his show 😁. This man is brilliant but you need certain amount of Brian to understand him.

I normally don't get offended by the jokes from black comedians for white people. Most of the times are tasteful and right. But in Griffin's case I found them truly racist. And man, you've got daughters and you're disrespecting women so much? I'm very disappointed by this special.

This is the kind of garbage washed-up artists release when they actually have nothing to produce, but want to still seem relevant. It's unfunny in an insulting manner. This is kind of show that requires you to buy-in to something you don't believe just to feel better about wasting your time or money. When every leftist comedian tries to cover the same material, it becomes difficult to say something fresh. Well, this, also wasn't fresh. Please have something funny to say (if there is a) next time.
So this was supposed to be funny? 8/10 Was it intelligent? 8/10 Was it relevant? 10/10 All of the above? 10/10 Was the subject matter covered balanced? 8/10 Overall laugh factor? 10/10

This is the most weak special of EG i saw. His material is weak. He is the one who is racist, he touches all the old material. He milked this cow and there is nothing new. It was just sad watching this. From voodoo to this weak attempt.
Normally I like Eddie Griffin but this was unbearable. So racist, tacky, and just plain not funny.

I don't understand all the negative reviews for his performance. Eddie is real, he doesn't sugar coat anything. He reveals and says what most people refuse to say or are afraid to admit. We all know racism is very real and rampant, more now than ever. To say Eddie is racist is ridiculous. He's calling people out, closeted racists and people who are trying to be polite with their racism. Things most people reveal about themselves behind closed doors, Eddie brings to the forefront! He may be vulgar in his delivery, but he is on point!
Great special very funny, even funnier is all the offended white people lol

Didn't find it funny... he used to be great. Every time he said all white people are basically stupid, lazy, who support Trump..I cringed. I loathe Trump. Never hated anyone like I hate him more that I've ever hated anyone.Had he called them the Trunters.... instead of all white people... I could at least cheered when he insulted them.

Donald Trump supporters would label this movie a zero if they could. Anyone who doesn't like the truth about America would label this a zero if they could. Eddie griffin is definitely in your face with this one,holds no punches and is sorry for nothing. You're either going going to like this a lot or absolutely hate it. I can guarantee the low ratings come strictly from offended people who either don't get or don't want to get the humor. If you have been an Eddie griffin fan for a long time,watch this,because when has he not been funny? Ignore the ratings,the humor will go over the head of most conservatives,trump supporters and sensitive people.

Eddie is definitely one of the funniest comics today. He has a natural gift for making one laugh. However, this is without a doubt his biggest failures. He is angry at almost everything and his deep seated hatred unfortunately shows. At the end he makes a failed attempt at explaining his comedy and tries to convince his audience he is only joking and we should understand and then blames us for not agreeing. With all the frustration in politics he could easily find a way to turn it to his advantage and make everyone laugh by uniting all. He only drives the terrible division further. He hides behind the "N" word so proudly and defiantly. I have enjoyed every comedy special he has done, but this one is simply awful. I can only hope he can get the help he needs and find humor in life somewhere.

WOW Eddie has done gone crazy himself. That was the most racist, violent, hate speech I believe I have ever heard. If the n-word (you know the one that only african-americans can use) was taken out of the monologue the show would have been 10 minutes. Somebody get Eddie some help before he hurts himself, his family or someone.

If it were possible to rate something lower than one star, I would. This deserves something like -4 stars. The whole thing is one long Anti-Trump, "All white people are racist" bs. The sheer hypocrisy of it is almost unbearable. After watching this appalling piece of excrement, I find hard to believe that I was ever a fan of Eddie Griffin.
Terrible Kat Williams need to teach him some things!

Ive always liked Eddie Griffin and i was excited to watch his special. I sat through half of it and literally every topic he brought up was how black people are great and white people are stupid. Its all just reverse racism. Honestly i cant say im a fan anymore. Being a white man with a black girlfriend of 2+ years, i disagree with almost everything he said. I also didnt laugh once. A chuckle here and there, but none of it was really funny.. Disappointed is an understatement...

The first show I watched from Todd Barry was Super Crazy from 2012. I thought it was okay, even though I find him a bit too static on scene. His jokes were okay, not all of them though, so I was curious if five years later he would have changed anything about his show. In Spicy Honey he's still very static, still no facial expressions or mimicing, the same routine as usual, he looks kind of bored on scene, so nothing changed there. His jokes are the kind of jokes that you hear but will never remember. This show wasn't better than Super Crazy so if you never watched any of his shows but still want to just pick Super Crazy then.
Todd Barry will never be a mainstream comedian because he is actually funny. This special is hilarious, just like everything he has ever done. Eight stars.

12/28/17. Yep, you can consider Barry the king of deadpan delivery. You have to pay attention lest you miss the line that will get you howling. Well, maybe not howling, but possibly several smirky har-hars. Yes, he's funny and worth catching.

It was so slow, boring and the crowd laughed at anything and everything that was really unusual, Save your time and money or watch it on Netflix if you are really bored. There are some funny moments but nothing more than a little giggle. Not a fan of his style it came across so flat, hope some others are? Spicy honey? more like bland sweeteners.

Never saw Todd Barry before. Netflix keeps on delivering specials, props to them. And props to Todd Barry. Way to show how different tastes can be (@asharf), for me it was a joke festival and i laughed my ass off. Maybe also because many jokes hit home and many remind me of friends - it just works. This guy looks so unsuspicious, hand in his pockets, moving with minimum possible effort on the stage - deadpan indeed. xD

How on earth does this classify as a comedy? It was so boring and the crowd just laughing at any random thing even before a joke has been said. Please save your money; time and insanity because u are going to need it after this dire crap.
Just LOVED the riffs on organizers. SOOO true. He puts it all so well and delivers it so effortlessly. Love the wry self deprecating boasting...is that paradox possible? Yes!! And so great. True wit!

I know Erik Griffin from Workaholics, a show that I really liked so I was curious about his stand-up comedy. For his first ever stand-up comedy I thought Erik Griffin did a pretty good job. Like plenty of others he's a slow starter but he grows during the show. In the beginning his jokes are not bad but not the greatest either but once he got the second gear in it got much better. There are some hilarious moments, like when he's getting to the kids subject. I had some good laughs what made this show a bit better than the usual stand-up comedians. Looking forward to another show.

The show is mildly amusing. Meaning there were some smiles, but I could not get why the people were laughing. Or was it canned laughs?Anyway, the title is misleading. Nothing contrarian on this show. Quite the opposite: cheap populism blended with some memories.

I enjoyed most of this comedy special, D.L. Hughley has a playful and fun way to do stand-up, and I laughed a lot. Some curveballs,meaning it wasn't everything that was funny to me, but it was overall a very good show, and I recommend it :)

This man has been hiding for a while. And honestly should go back. Most of his jokes were to stir up more racial issues than anything else. Why are so many comdians using this as there go to rather than just making a joke. Stop helping the media pull us apart. And even if you lol past that it really wasn't that funny at all. I got more of a laugh out of his outfit.

I turned 45 last year. Listening to this even growing up in New Zealand in the 1980s was 80% the same experience. There were so many points of reference that totally was representative of my home life. The same type of mom. The similar types of experience as an elder sibling. The low rating only shows that those who watched it around the world did not experience what almost 50% of non-white kids experienced. Look at what Russell Peters talks about from the Indian POV, I am Ind0-Fijian Kiwi myself, so related with that . Anyway, it could be the R rated language for the low rating as well.The Fix in which DL currently is on Nextflix is worth watching as well.

I could only watch this a few minutes before I was bored and unimpressed. Joke about whatever you like, I don't care, but jokes don't land when they rely on completely wrong statistics to make a racially motivated point.
It is an hour long special rehashing 2017 American news. I really can't find the jokes. Watch Raw, and Delirious instead, they hold up.
D.L. Hughley always delivers a good show! This one is no exception. You won't be disappointed.
I made it 20 minutes of complaining about white people and throwing around in-funny used up political jokes before I had enough. No real original content, very disappointed.
Damn, I use to admire D.L. Hughley, but his recycled jokes, transphobic stance are no longer funny. I would not recommend this show.

The show starts off with DL Hughley stating popular opinion after popular opinion to cheers and applause with a few light jokes sprinkled in to make sure people remember he is a comedian. I was hoping from the title that there would be some contrarianism, but it was just affirmation of consensus, and I gave up about halfway through of there being anything but lukewarm jokes that reaffirm commonly held beliefs.

Enjoyed the typical D.L Hughley quick wit. I like him as a human being and find him very entertaining as a stand up comedian. I always look forward to his stand up specials and this one didn't disappoint.

Never really been a fan but my husband and I decided to watch on Netflix and man ole man we were laughing from beginning to end..DL has evolved as a stand up comic in a major way..And again was ,never a big fan but I am now. He killed it with this stand up..New DL fan

I went into "Oh, Hello" knowing very little, and I think that's the best way to go into this. "Oh, Hello" is a weird and stupidly brilliant mix of stand-up and theatre, and as a passionate fan of both of these mediums, I absolutely loved the way Nick Kroll and John Mulaney blended and created this performance. "Oh, Hello" is unique, original, and interesting, and should be considered essential for theatre and stand-up fans. The characters of George and Gil are well executed and extremely fun to watch, and I absolutely love this special. It is one of the most quotable pieces I have ever seen. Don't get me wrong, there are flaws here. The show tries to tackle a lot of different things; an interview, standup, a story, a "ballet", and all these elements are well meaning and pretty well executed, but sometimes, particularly during the interview, they feel a little bit like lulls in the performance. A lot of the jokes, as well, are very New York based, about specific parts of living in and being in New York city, and if you're not familiar with NYC then these might go over your head, even though they're quite poignant and funny. That being said, the elements that Kroll and Mulaney introduce here are extremely interesting and entertaining, and make the show incredibly unique and fun to watch, and if you like performance art of really any form, you'll probably enjoy this. "Oh, Hello" is an excellent example the great kind of creative content a platform like Netflix can provide, and is definitely deserving of at least one watch. 9.5/10

Found it mildly humorous but think it's too regional specific.I'd imagine if your American, or more specifically from New York, it's probably absolutely hilarious but unfortunately humour that really doesn't cross the pond.A disjointed and bizarre show that I only watched on Netflix because it mentioned Michael J Fox and for that, I only needed to watch the 7min trailer rather than the whole show.

I'm not really a Broadway person, but I love John Mulaney and Nick Kroll so I had to check this out. This show is absolutely hilarious. My friend and I were laughing the entire time. They make fun of a lot of tropes in theater which great. Their characters George and Gil are so funny. There are a lot of New York related jokes that probably make the most sense to people who are actually from New York, but I still found it very entertaining.

"Oh, Hello" is the marriage of two incredibly talented comedians into one fantastic act. Apart, both Mulaney and Kroll are funny but their chemistry together is something magical. My only reservation about their project is the fact that some of the humor might not carry over to non-American audiences - I live in the States so it isn't an issue for me, but jokes about NYC might be less funny without context. Regardless, a great show and one of the few great Netflix specials.

Although I never saw the creation of Gil & George (2005 performing at alt comedy rooms) I feel like I've been on an amazing journey with them. Nick and John's ability to riff off each other is almost effortless.Listening to them on the podcast Comedy Bang Bang (hosted by Hot Saucerman) was my first experience and whenever they dropped by the show, they were funny to a degree of perfection.Gil and George's sketch segment on Kroll Show called Too Much Tuba really made me realize how much I hate tuna, and for that I am eternally grateful.I don't know them and they don't know me, but I was proud of them regardless when Oh Hello turned into a Broadway show. I'm not in theater but performing on Broadway seems like a pretty big deal. I loved when John got a Swedish Fish in his teeth. I love when Nick called the audience poor. I loved Steve Martin. But mostly, I loved when Nick accidentally sang Movin Out by Billy Joel.And a huge shout out to Anna who does their old man makeup. They look old as hell. You nailed it.

Full disclosure- if you don't enjoy Broadway shows, subtract one star from the rating, and if you don't live in New York, subtract another. The humor is unapologetically slanted to a New York theater audience, but it is, after all, a limited run Broadway show.Mulaney and Kroll inhabit their characters so comfortably and completely that one tends to forget the men behind them. A two-hour show of self- absorbed, borderline delusional caricatures is so reminiscent of Steve Martin's early comedy that his cameo in the middle of the show feels like a foregone conclusion.The jokes are fast paced but the premise never seems rushed. The performance is loose, but scripted and theatrical enough to feel substantial. I've watched it twice. Highly, highly recommended to comedy fans.

What the hell... this is so poor and so not funny, maybe if you are a New Yorker you might think it is. I wanted a good laugh and so got this film. It's vaguely and slightly amusing at the start but then just bores. How these two make a living out of this poor form of writing is hard to believe. Don't waste your time unless you somehow like these guys humor, I did not get it at all and regretted watching this movie.

So the person who wrote the bad review must be jealous of John and nick bc they are both god of the free world but this movie/play was hilarious. It is was god watches in his free time. John and Nick are two of the funniest comedians of our time and this show is perfectly chaotic. God I love it.
If you like John Mulaney's standup, you'll appreciate this show. I loved it!

My 2 favorite comedians at the top of their game! I'm not from NY. And not a Broadway fan. But I saw this show live and on Netflix and loved it both times! The humor isn't for everyone I guess, but it was 100% for me.

Daniel Tosh brings his high-speed stream of consciousness delivery on stand-up tour and, here, in a concert film recorded in San Francisco .... well, on video, almost certainly, and on Comedy Central, home of his often gross but always sardonic TOSH.0 TV show.I'm a fan of his work, even when he constantly crosses the line between humorous transgression and the disgusting variety. Here he stays more securely on the safe line of the divide but his constant willingness to say what we think but rarely dare to say is a lot of fun.My one issue with watching this on TV is the constant commercial interruptions. They interrupt the speed and flow of the jokes and it takes too long to bring the watcher up to speed again. This is one worth seeing on DVD or, when it shows up, on Comedy Central on Demand, which doesn't have insurance commercials every three minutes.

I enjoy Daniel Tosh's comedy. I find it satirical and clever. It is purposely offensive and in this special most of his targets are on-point. I found this installment very funny, but a little slower than Completely Serious and People Pleaser. I wouldn't miss this one if you are a fan of him or standup comedy in general, though.

Funny, but nowhere near as funny as 'Completely Serious' was. I'm a big fan of his in general, but it just seemed like he was trying too hard on this one. His real talent is being casually outrageous, but in 'Happy Thoughts' many of the jokes came off as somewhat contrived and formulaic, not to mention pandering to the crowd... nothing brilliant about calling the founding fathers 'racist scumbags' in front of a San Francisco crowd, and honestly, that's kinda out of line either way (and yes, I'm okay with the jokes about having sex with a baby, but draw the line at the founding fathers, call me crazy).Had a lot of funny moments and is worth watching to be sure, but don't expect magic.

First time I saw a show from Russell Peters was Notorious from 2013, which I liked so I was curious about his early work and oh boy this was a good idea. Outsourced is even funnier, I laughed throughout his whole set. The tone is set after just five seconds, whilst he's introducing himself and looking at the audience, checking what ethnicities are present, his show will stay with the race topic from beginning till the end. Some might find that offending, all those stereotypes, but in all honesty it was just funny how he switched from one race to another, from on accent or dialect to another, he's very talented in that domain. All his jokes are well written, but even his interaction with the audience that will require some improvisation is on top. He just has a very large funny bone. I can't wait to watch another show from him, maybe he won't play the race card in the next one, I don't really know, but it would be interesting to see if he can manage the same level of humor with other topics. That said Outsourced is more then an hour of fun and laughter, certainly worth watching.

Russell Peters is a guy who borrows topics that are largely untouched by the usual media and creates jokes out of it. Although this was my first time watching him, I laughed my stomach off.Talking heavily about racism, breaking the stereotypes and finally advising the Americans to follow the other world culture when it comes to parenting are the highlights of this 1 hour long, extremely funny TV movie. His timings are great, not to mention how good his memory is.Observational comedy has been brought up by this guy. He relates all his jokes and that's why they are hilarious. It went slightly boring towards the end, but in shows like this, few downs don't turn you off. Highly Recommended! You'll be amazed with which topics he chooses and uses satire to bring out roars in us.

Russel Peters is popular, but he gets a lot of criticism for playing the race card too much. I don't know if he's doing it too much, there's a lot of humor to be found in race relations and Peters' comedy isn't as tasteless as it could be, and it's occasionally quite funny. He does good impressions and though his written jokes are funny enough the best parts of the concert are the improvised bits when he interacts with the audience, which he does a lot.If racial humor just isn't your thing, "Russel Peters: Outsourced" just isn't something you should watch. As someone who thinks it can be funny, if a little irritating at times, I enjoyed this DVD, although his previous concert was far superior.7/10

This guy is hilarious, he is a rare find, buy this DVD it is really funny, you will pee your pants it is so good. Coming from an Indo-Canadian comedian Russell Peters is the best in the business. He takes shots at all the ethnicities and there are no boundaries he doesn't cross, Whether you are white, black, brown or whatever, you are all going to get it. His comedy is not meant to insult its there to make everyone realize we all have some flaws and he brings out the funny side in it. He can nail down accents on a dime whether its the cheap Asian guy or the abusive Indian father to the big African guy with a click in his name. His show has got it all, go check it out you won't be disappointed with this talented comedian.

Iliza is an attractive and energetic performer, but I feel she sometimes lingers too long on one particular topic (like, for example, the weather) and the show loses its impetus. With that said, I liked this standup special enough to be watching more from her. **1/2 out of 4.
Not my favorite comedian kind of meh if you dont like one you probably wont like any of her specials

I'm at special number 3 right now and all she talks about is dating and LA white girls relatable stuff that probably any girl outside LA wouldn't really relate to. I'm a dude so maybe i'm wrong here about the LA white girl thing but dating humor seems to be her main shtick.It's better than Elder Millenial still feminist but way less preachy. She actually admit in this one that woman cause their own troubles and are crazy sometimes which is good cause in Elder Millenial it seems to all be men fault and society.But she still have funny jokes that land. The thing flow well. Her number about how girls like Fall is very funny. The number about girls fighting just to know if they can blame the guy even if it's 100% their fault is hilarious.Enjoyed it. It was more abrasive and less "Yass Queen" than Elder.Side note, She ends a lot of punchlines with like 2 easy words that can be hashtagged. And the hashtags appear on screen and it's really distracting i don't like that.

In this special Iliza's act was really well put together and very funny. Unlike her special War Paint there seemed to be fewer long, unfunny bits, and some of the more repetitive parts from that special were toned down (the weird goat/sheep noises).So far this has been her peak, and it deserves to be watched.
For me, this show was a complete waste of time. The jokes are cringeworthy in a way that almost made me angry.

Can't get enough of Iliza. Wouldn't say I have a favourite of her specials but this would be up there. It seems almost inhuman for somebody to have that much wit and energy and stay on top form each and every joke. I watch her expecting some sort of error or F up and it doesn't happen. There is no one like herLong live the demand for Iliza so it means she'll keep producing these shows. I was lucky enough to meet her at a corporate event she hosted and was pleasantly relived at how completely and utterly down to earth she was.The world needs more Ilizas and I am a dedicated fan. This special is nothing short of pure genius.Looking forward to more 😘

This was the first time that I watched any of Kevin James stand-up comedy. Prior to watching "Never Don't Give Up", I have only been familiar with his work in TV series and movies.I must say that I was more than impressed. Sure, I knew that he did have a funny bone. But he was so at home on the stage, that it felt very natural.His jokes were good and well-delivered, and there were a good amount of laughs throughout the course of the show.If you like Kevin James in the comedy on TV and movies, then you should definitely also take the time to watch this show. I was genuinely entertained and had some very nice laughs as he spewed forth his jokes and punchlines.

This is the kind of stand up comedy I just watch out of boredom, not expecting much entertainment. It's just passable, not really my kind of humor, at least not for a stand up comedy, which I like to be provocative, on the edge, wrong and sarcastic. For that I have to watch Jim Jefferies, Frankie Boyle, Ricky Gervais and others, because Kevin James does not belong in that list, he's way too soft for that level of humor. But I have not been yawning, and that's something, it was like I said just passable. But I doubt I will watch another stand up comedy from him, I'll just stick with the movies where he appears in.
4/29/18. This was ok for a stand-up comedy show. Not very original, but the humor was clean and not offensive. I like him better in movies.
Looks like Kevin didn't have many writers to 'create' his comic situations. Ten minutes in and I decided that a drink was I order to pass the next 50 minutes. Disappointed.

Terrible. This just consited of joked that were so old that even 40+ yrs already posted them as minion memes on facebook. I broke up after a while, I skipped ahead to see if it would get better, but nah.
If you liked king of queens you will like this. Worth a watch.
I really liked this one. It was very funny. Being objective, I have to say that he lingered on some jokes too long but overall I was heartily laughing throughout.

I went into watching this skeptical of if Kevin James would be funny as a stand up comedian because I only know him from his movies and TV Shows, all of which I like, except for Paul Blart Mall Cop 2. I thought that this was very funny!Pros: Family friendly. Very clean comedy, which I love. And I laughed throughout. Cons: He lingered on some jokes too long, but not too much where it really bothered me.

This is kevin's first stand up special in 17 years, since his first, and only, 'sweat the small stuff' in 2001. whilst not as energetic or memorable, 'never don't give up' covers a wider variety of topics.the title is a reference to one of the jokes. though it doesn't serve as a crucial focal point. the best material post 'sweat the small stuff' is compiled into an hour. this format works well as nothing drags, and it keeps things at a fast pace. yet enough time was spent fleshing out each bit, so it doesn't feel rushed. the trailer honestly doesn't do it justice.the purple backdrop is a nice touch. kevin isn't camouflaged in black this time around. presentation is kept very simple; no need for cut scenes or intermissions as this isn't a television broadcast, or home media.the audience doesn't seem to be as lively, and I even suspect that some of the laughter may be canned - due to it sometimes not matching their body language. of course there are plenty of laughs, but they were all even levelled across the board. none of the bits stood out above others in terms of their reactions.kevin is still animated; his stories are peppered with facial expressions and mimes.much of his act throughout the years has been based on frustration. however, this marks the first time that it has been directed towards certain groups of people. his age is starting to show, and that is reflected in the way he sees the world. he knows what he knows and isn't interested in learning anything new. there's an 'intolerance' that is worrisome, though not alarming...clean humour has also been long associated with kevin's brand. he was never one to use any 'major' profanities or lewdness. here is no exception, in fact, this seems cleaner than 'sweat..' in that respect. however, there are some 'gross out' jokes and references to adult life that are not 'family friendly' as advertised, or suitable for the squeamish.this may not have been exactly the sequel I was waiting for, but it's a nice addition nonetheless. stand up comedy is kevin's foundation. it's what he does best. in fact, it would be nice if he could focus on this medium exclusively, and develop a series of specials. just like his peers brian regan and jim gaffigan have.

In my opinion it felt like he didn't have anything drastically new or original so for the first half it felt like he was just trying to feel out the crowd - more than he was unapologetically slamming them with some humor.As I saw in some other reviews I have to agree that the second half was better and the improv-crowd comedy brought it home for a good close-out. In fact, the tattoo bits were probably my favorite.Not completely family friendly so I would screen it before watching it with your kids if that's one of your concerns.It was very close to a 6 for me but the ending gave it a little boost. As you can see from other reviewers the opinions widely vary so it really just depends on who you are. But the main consent is that it definitely wasn't a 10.

The first half was not funny at all in my opinion. He seemed almost like hew as faking being mad for the sake of the routine. Also the joke all seemed worn out. Kinda like the jokes you make with your family but you know every other family has also already made them. I stoped about 25 mins in I think because I was not enjoying it. Went back today to finish it because I like completing shows, and it was much better. Second half was funny and he seemed to easy up on the pseudo mad attitude. If the whole show was like the second half, I would have ranked it and 8.

My review may be biased because I'm not really a fan of Kevin James' TV or movie career, but I love stand up and figured I'd give this a shot. The jokes were pretty unoriginal, run-of-the-mill material I'd hear at any local dive comedy club. He jokes about being fat, men with food allergies needing to "man up" and (...honestly, I don't even remember much of the rest of his set) were all pretty boring and outdated. It was just generic. I did find the jokes about his kids to be pretty funny. I also enjoyed his crowd work (the bits about tattoos made me chuckle). However, I'm pretty sure his joke about his kid sneezing into his mouth was ripped off of Louis CK's bit about his daughter coughing into his mouth. If you're looking for some mildly amusing background noise, go ahead and put this on. Nothing special though.

A couple of slow sections in the routine but for the majority it was absolutely side splitting! I love the fact I could sit with my kids watching it and still laugh because there were no profanities. Big thumbs up!

While certain sections felt a bit slow or dull, it was a good laugh for most of it. Got to give props to Kevin for managing a solid hour with no cursing or swearing and still keeping it for the most part laugh out loud funny. The bit with his kids was a lot of fun, as was the food intolerance jokes. I honestly laughed at those. The Tattoo bits were slightly dull. Though he does a good job at the "improv" with the different tattoos of audience members. It is a departure from his normal over the top comedy in his movies though. So don't expect the Kevin James from Paul Blart or Adam Sandler's endeavours. Think more of Kevin James in King of Queens, and Hitch. Still funny but less outrageous. A good solid hour for pretty much any audience unless you are sensitive about lactose intolerance.
Some parts were a little boring but most of his special were funny and I laughed a lot

This set is beyond great. Kevin James has perfect delivery, no matter the bit. Not as funny as his Sweat The Small Stuff show from years ago but as that was beyond a masterpiece and regarded as one of the best standup shows of the early 00's any thing after it makes it tough to compete. Never Don't Give Up is still absolutely hilarious and a great watch. I've seen it twice. It's not going to set records, but it's still better than the majority of Netflix specials and other comedy specials circulating today. Especially when considering the fact that he manages to stay insanely funny while staying family friendly. That's not as easy as it sounds it comedy, it's like playing without a crutch. He's a fantastic standup with his delivery of his simple yet relatable putting him levels above other comics!

First of all. He had me laughing since the beginning. The show is a very organic one, He talks about stuff he really lives, so it's pretty genuine. Also mixes a little crowd fun which he manages awesome. I loved it and would watch and recommend it to anybody who wants to have a great time with Kevin's unique style.
It was really funny! A lot better than expected. He made very good jokes!

Cedric the Entertainer is an old man. And so his point of view is about old man fears. Not quite funny. He is a professional. And he has a good act. A professional act. But it takes more to be funny. And usually the audience laughs at the ghetto talk as a cue: this is supposed to be funny.Contact me with Questions, Comments or Suggestions ryitfork @ bitmail.ch

But instead of "little white baby on a keychain" he changed it to "little yorkie on a keychain".He's pandering to an exclusively black audience and trying to relate to them hard, but really trough nothing funny, just low effort generic statements like "black people this, right?", "white people that, right?", "cops killing black kids, obama good, trump bad, right?".And that's fine, exploit your demographic for cash, but don't steal jokes from the greatest comedian ever just because he's dead. You're like the Brian Regan of black people - the safest, most timid, predictable jokes ever - I liked your singing but the rest was really just okay and I expected something great eventhough it's the first time I've seen you, because that entrance was epic and you seemed pretty likeable at first. But it's just a charade, isn't it. Don't steal your racist jokes from Patrice, he was able to pull them off, you're not.

This show is a combination of several shows but it is pure fun and outrageously hilarious as well. Its part Carol Burnett,the hijinks of In Living Color and MAD TV,the wit of Saturday Night Live,and the stylish settings of Flip Wilson and Steve Harvey. Basically Cedric The Entertainer has brought the variety show format back to its prime which hasn't been seen like this in a long time. It is a Wednesday night laugh out loud riot especially the part where Cedric plays the food serving old woman who insults people and the part where actress Wendy Raquel Robinson plays a ghetto mama who does a hilarious court segment. Its a hilarious half-hour of fun.

Cedric the Entertainer Presents is a great show to follow The Bernice Mac Show since both fellas Kings Of Comedy. While Berine show is a situation comedy, Cedric's is a variety show in the form of Flip Wilson. The sketch where Cedric played the lunch lady put tears in my eyes. Check this one out.

Network: Fox; Genre: Variety, Sketch Comedy; Content Rating: TV-PG (for language and scatological humor); Available: DVD; Classification: Contemporary (star range: 1 - 4); Season Reviewed: Complete Series (2 seasons) The tombstone was built on the head of "Cedric the Entertainer Presents" the minute Cedric the Entertainer uttered the words "variety show". Many have tried to resurrect the long-dead prime-time variety show and all have failed, notably Dana Carvey in a short-lived 1998 sketch series.There are moments in "Presents", such as an opening dance number where the comic emerges from a troop of scantly-clad dancers, "The Sensations", when the show briefly hearkens back to the days of Donnie and Marie Osmond but gives it a new millennial twist. The host on stage, in front of a visible audience, doing whatever he wanted for the half hour. There is something admirable in the attempt. Much of the time however, "Presents" is more "Mad TV" with silly, grotesquely unfunny sketches filled with 4th wall breaking musical numbers. Second only to a daytime talk show (Wayne Brady knows that), nothing is quite as stifling to talent or lowering in dignity as a variety series. And the pressure to fill 22 minutes worth of slam-bang, all different, quality sketches or risk the audience changing the channel is enough to drive anyone insane. Coming off of his "Kings of Comedy Tour" movie, the blisteringly funny Cedric the Entertainer seems like a strange fit for a variety show. The guy , in fact, a renaissance man. He sings, he dances, and he does more than a lot of both in this show. Probably more than contemporary audiences want to see. Like his "Kings" co-star Bernie Mac, he is neutered to broadcast network television standards here, forced to mellow out and appeal to demographics while paired with a troop of ensemble players whom he has little chemistry with. Of the group J. B. Smoove is the funniest - often upstaging Cedric. The problem (and I hate to use that cliché) is that the Entertainer just doesn't make this show his own. He doesn't use the platform to bring us his vision, through his voice. The show was going to be canceled anyway, people just don't watch variety shows each week the way they did decades ago, he should have said "to hell with it" and shaped the show into whatever outrageous thing he wanted - this sure doesn't seem like it - and gone down with the ship. Instead, we've got him running through the same annoying character sketches, such as a regularly appearing Cafeteria lunch lady and a musical therapist Dr. Love. Many have tried and all have failed, so the prime-time sketch comedy series still remains an archaic genre. (Well, as of this writing Dave Chappelle has done it and done it in spades, but transporting back to when this show was running in 2002, "Chappelle's Show" has yet to take off). "Presents" is almost cringe-worthy and not worth the time except for those who want to see Cedric the Entertainer embarrassing himself and hear tire racial stereotype jokes. Zero laughs.* / 4

I was laughing real hard when I saw the season premiere, but it seemed to go downhill from there. My 2 favorite segments of the show was The Cafeteria Lady and Que Hora Es? Well, Que Hora Es? was only funny the first time. Each time after that it was the same thing at a different setting. Cafeteria lady is very similar. There are other segments which show every few weeks, but they just aren't that funny to me anymore. Yet many people will probably be able to watch this every week and get a good laugh.

Not as funny as Dave Chappelle's show but a lot better than Wayne Brady's, Cedric's show made me chuckle a few times, but he and his ensemble can't carry a whole half-hour show. Characters like the Cafeteria Lady got old before the sketch ended. However, it was good for Jerry Minor to get work again after getting fired from SNL. Still, the Flip Wilson days have come and gone, you know what I mean?

This show is truly a "In Living Color" wannabe. I was not entertained nor did I laugh once while watching this show. Cedric is a funny guy, but I think he should stick to stand up. If Fox wants to entertain us or make us REALLY laugh, maybe they should show reruns of "In Living Color".

I checked out "Cedric the Entertainer Presents" last night for the first time, at the behest of several co-workers of mine. Well, what can I say? Do the words "In Living Color" ring any bells? Except, "In Living Color" was more of an ensemble cast, whereas "Cedric the Entertainer Presents" merely serves as a self-indulgent ego stroke to an already obviously inflated ego- "Original Kings of Comedy"??? GET REAL!!! Not only is "Cedric the Entertainer Presents" not funny, it's not even entertaining! It's been done before, and done WAY better by the Brothers' Wayans.Oh, and a note to Cedric...people who usually refer to themselves by what they "do" (i.e. Cedric the Entertainer), usually it means that they aren't very good at it and need to convince people that they actually are...some food for thought.

I wonder why people think this show stinks. It's a great show. Some people say the jokes are old (well, maybe), but people don't care about how old it is as long as they're funny and keep you laughing. The drama is good, too. The dancers support the show, but actors/actresses made it great.

Like most fans of Adam Sandler, I loved his movies in the 90's, but his recent stuff not so much.This special was really good though. Most of the songs and most of the jokes worked. I did not expect that at all. Go out of your way to watch this special.

Being an avid fan of Adam Sandler and enjoying many of his films, had relatively no expectations about this stand up special. This was quite a well done effort and many of his stand up jokes were funny and didn't come off as rushed. We could tell he came prepared and had enough material.It was well edited with showing him performing at different venues. A lot of interesting and funny songs included, and possibly the highlight was the Chris Farley tribute near the end. Also a surprise cameo by Rob Schneider to close the show was great. Overall this Netflix special was better than expected.

Where's my sense of humor? I thought I always got it, but how come I didn't and couldn't laugh even once for this guy's crap? The problem might be still mine since I never thought this guy is funny, not in the least. The audiences laughed almost every word this guy said and sang, but were those words or the terrible sound he made as singing really that funny? Or they just wanted to fool themselves and trying to make every penny they spent on this dude worth? I've paid more attention to these attendances' moronic reactions to whatever the guy did and thought their stupid and senseless laughs were more entertaining funny than this dude's boring crap.

I have not always liked Adam Sandler's form of comedy or his movies. In fact many times I just could not understand what I was missing because I found him to be very annoying rather than funny...however I watched this out of curiosity and I have to say I was pleasantly surprised.Comedy is very subjective - not every comic will appeal to every person. Sometimes comedy is funnier to you at certain points or times in your life than others. Now that I'm older I find different things funny than I used to. Adam Sandler is older now and has been a husband for many years and is a father so I think his comedy has changed as well. He has obviously matured and it seems he "gets" it now. Life is completely absurd and everyone and everything is annoying and you realize how truly mundane and pointless life can be. People are cruel and life can be hard, disappointing, heartbreaking and unfulfilling. As you get older you learn to cope by finding the humor in all of it. If you don't laugh...you'll cry. Therefore I found this special to be hilarious because he's poking fun and making light of everyday life and people that we have all encountered. I was laughing throughout the whole thing because it's relatable and made me feel like I'm not the only one who thinks these thoughts about stuff.Also the tribute to Chris Farley and also to his wife and kids was very touching. It made me cry. It showed me that Adam Sandler has definitely matured. It also shows you how deeply he cares about his family and friends. He seems to be very loyal. He employs family and friends. Also what other comic has ever done a tribute to someone who has been gone for almost 21 years during their own set? I've never seen that. He could have used the time to keep the focus on himself but instead he chose to honor a dear friend who he obviously loved and cared for very deeply. All I can say is - if my son had a friend like that it would touch me very deeply and make me very happy to see that his friend is keeping his memory alive way long after everyone else has forgotten about him.If I were just rating AS on his comedy maybe I wouldn't have given this a 10 because he does seem to be very tired and emotionless in many of the bits - almost like he's doing this just to satisfy his contract with Netflix BUT since this is a special there are more elements to it than just his comedy. I felt that his piano playing sidekick was funny and enjoyable to watch and of course the tributes were really a beautiful touch so therefore I'm giving this a 10 and I rarely give 10's.If you watch this and only rate it based on his comedy alone then you must be kind of heartless because the tributes alone are worth 10's. They are very touching and so beautifully and lovingly compiled. Those need to count for something.

This was a Fantastic performance. When he did that song at the End about Chris Farley that was alot of RESPECT FOR THE ONES YOU LOVE. Wow and that Song was Fantastic it was Funny great, and the phones up top were fantastic. That song about his Wife was also great. That song was at least 6 minutes long. Comparing to all his other ones. The look on his face and his eyes. It was done straight from the Heart. Also he made another Film about his very FIRST MAN THAT HELPED HIM GET FAMASE CALLED????? If you are a REAL FAN YOU CAN FIGURE IT OUT BUT THAT FILM WAS ALSO TERRIFIC WONDERFUL. I Will give you a Hint over 250 Stars made a apperinice in the FILM. IT WAS A PRETTY GOOD FILM. Who knows what FILM that is?????

Is this great? No. Is it hilarious? No. That said it had it's moments and looked like Sandler was having fun. I enjoyed it. I can't say that about most anything Sandler has made recently which may have skewed my score but oh well. He brought back his goofy singing and stuff which got him noticed in the first place. He also had a touching song about Chris Farley which alone made it worth the watch for me.

He's in all of those terrible movies but in this special - he's funny, has tons of skills, really a cool guy.If you're avoiding this like a plague because you expect it to be "like an Adam Sandler movie" - well, don't, it's nothing like it. Gives a good perspective on the guy outside of the awful Hollywood movie cash-in cancer bubble.I'd prefer it if it was just stand up but it's much more than that and it's super respectable all that he does, even if I just want the stand up. Give it a watch!

Once a breakout star of SNL, Adam Sandler has gradually become a running joke with his selection of terrible movies, going from classics like 'Billy Madison', 'Happy Gilmore' 'The Waterboy' and 'The Wedding Singer' to self-indulgent garbage like the Grown Ups franchise and regularly including best mates Rob Schneider and Kevin James in his projects.This Netflix special will go a long way to winning back Sandler's fans. It's funny (with Sandler putting on the silly voices from his early movies), dirty, clever and touching, with a compilation of stand up shows and a surprise subway appearance in its 70 minute duration.Despite being over 50, Sandler still brings out the dirty jokes amongst family stories and a bunch of funny, silly little songs (with his keyboardist Dan Bulla and a funny cameo from Schneider). The songs are so ridiculous that Sandler often cracks up over them. Sandler uses relatable, observational humour and ramps it to ridiculous levels, with sudden and unexpected punchlines. One song has Sandler playing the hero in a series of dangerous scenarios (crashing plane, runaway train, a choking old lady in a restaurant) but they all end badly because Sandler admits he has no idea what he's doing.Highlights included the "Wallet, Phone, Keys" rap than went viral on social media, an emotional tribute song to Chris Farley (including a brilliant electric guitar solo from Sandler and a video compilation of Farley's life) and a nice song about Sandler's wife (with the chorus "growing old with you").If you've ever loved Sandler, '100% Fresh' is a must watch, if only to prove Sandler's still funny after all these years.
Ehh ok. I laughed a couple times but it was not great like how people are hyping it up

Adam Sandler you had me Laugh and Cry. I was in TEARS when you had that song ABOUT Chris Farley IT WAS AWESOME. You are a Champion TRUE FRIEND. I BROKE INTO TEARS. MY GOD I MISS HIS MOVIES. THANKS FOR THE REMINDER OF HIS WORK. This was one of the BEST STAND UP SHOWS I EVERY SEEN. THAT VERY LAST SONG. WAS ANOTHER REMINDER OF YOUR WORK. THOSE TEARS IN YOUR EYES WAS THE WORK OF A REAL MAN. THAT WAS PROOF. THAT YOU ARE VERY PROUD OF WHAT YOU DO. THIS STAND UP SHOW HIT THE HEART AND COMEDY. THANK YOU VERY MUCH IT MADE MY WEEK BRIGHTING UP MR. SANDLER. YOU ARE THE MAN.

The form of comedy here is taking a subject that people in general have a beef against..like ridehailing and then making a short song ditty about with nothing insightful. That something differentiates standup comedy from just your funny friend or coworker.It's bad enough that the laugh from the audience sounds like a forced laugh track on a daytime sitcom.

I was surprised by this. It was actually funny and goes back to his earlier style comedy. His other new Netflix movies have stunk to high heaven and I really was starting to think he'd totally lost it. If you like his early films and SNL I recommend this.
Its clever and very music oriented. It's not a cash grab like his other stuff. Seems genuine. I liked it. But as others said if you didn't grow up on Adam Sandler you won't enjoy it

Watched 1/6/19I was feeling nostalgic, I was thinking about Billy Madison and Happy Gilmore and Big Daddy. I don't know what was going on that night but I wanted a little piece of comedic comfort from my childhood. I had heard about Adam Sandler's new stand up, I also heard it was really good. This isn't a shock to me, I know if you take Sandler out of the same formulaic comedies he's been cast in since the 90's the guy can really perform. We see his depth as a performer in Punch Drunk Love but also his comedy albums are works of musical genius in their own right. Ode to My Car is still one of the funniest things I've ever heard. So I queued it up and for the next 73 minutes was taken through an unexpectedly emotional journey.Comedy is tough to review because it's too subjective. But I will say Sandler's swagger and delivery has gotten even better, his musical songs were hilarious and the entire production cuts seamlessly and cleverly through different venues and sets. We see some behinds the scenes work too, that sort of lifts the curtain on the whole thing. He does the "I'm too old for this s--t" act but it isn't jaded or cynical, he isn't harsh or gatekeeping, he actually doesn't punch down at all. It's still a little raunchy too, it's great comedy. His jokes have an edge but his delivery and demeanor is so humble and earnest.The laughs are consistent and I was laughing almost the entire time, but the set takes a deeply emotional turn as Sandler plays a musical tribute to one of his closest friends Chris Farley. The song made me cry, flat out I'm not ashamed or embarrassed to admit it. Chris Farley died when I was 5 years old, I didn't really discover that until I was 12? I was always watching his SNL skits and films and was so deeply influenced seeing a fellow heavy weight perform and act like he did. Sandler's tribute is naturally sad and sentimental but also musically it's beautiful and comedic. The lyric that got me was: "We'd tell him slow down or you'll end up like Belushi and Candy. He said those guys are my heroes. That's all fine and dandy."Adam Sandler's 100% Fresh is clearly a tongue in cheek reference to his films consistently getting low reviews, and he doesn't say one bad thing other than a joke in which his lovingly jokes about hoping the critics all die. It was sweet and funny. I'll admit I really don't watch Sandler's newer comedies. The most recent one I saw was Click but I've heard plenty about Zohan and Jack and Jill and Grown Ups and rather than contribute to the vile stuff people say about it, I just choose to not get involved. I know I'm probably not going to enjoy the flicks so I just pass on them. I don't get why so many people say he should quit or more vulgarly should "f-----g kill himself" it was the same deal with George Lucas. He has every reason to be bitter and rude to fans and he isn't, his stand up is just him being him. Not giving a care if people don't like it but being humble and thankful to the fans who have stuck by him over the years.I can't recommend this special enough and I am actually really excited to hopefully hear more from the "Sand-Man," I hear he was cast in the upcoming Safdie Brothers film "Uncut Gems," which is a promising start for his new projects. If you have 73 minutes and a Netflix account. Give this a shot, it's truly worth it. If you don't have Netflix maybe it's time to text your ex and patch things up for a night.This review is heavily censored due to IMDB TOS It really is 100% Fresh
I tried to laugh but I couldn't. That's it. Can't find any more words to describe it.
Seriously though, his takes on rap are hilarious, especially "phone wallet keys" where he makes fun of mumble rap via the lens of a dad. Barmitsva boy is a great one as well.

I have never been a huge fan of Adam Sandler. I feel like he was extremely over rated, and constantly just played the same sort of role and always had the same type of humor.However, maybe it's because I haven't seen him for a while, this was actually quite enjoyable. I have recommended it to my friends as there are some real good moment.Worth the watch!

Throughout the 73 minutes including credits I didn't belly laugh once. Sure, I smiled and chuckled (somewhat forcedly, admittedly) a couple of times but this is some very unfunny stand up 'comedy'. The worst thing about watching the show from the TV is listening to the audience who laughed even at points in the jokes which weren't punchlines. In essence the routine is discussing going about something in everyday life and then inserting something random/crude or vice versa.If Adam Sandler intends to do more stand up then he needs to work on his routine. If an agent saw this as someone's first attempt to break into the business then, quite simply, they wouldn't be doing another show for a long while.

I watched this on Netflix about a day after it came out. I didn't know what to expect because I had never seen Adam Sandler's stand up comedy before. Well, after watching this, I know I won't be watching anymore of it! Do not waste your time and don't listen to the bot reviews. This Sucks!

I like Adam Sandler, and I didn't like this. I wasn't surprise that he started singing so quickly after, I was surprise at how much singing he did do. It's not that funny anymore. This is not a comedy, or anything well thought out. It is as far as fresh, as anything can be. This act went bad 20 years ago. He can do better, he is not putting much effort into his work now. I wish him the best, just please don't bother with putting out stuff like this.

I like Adam Sandler in the way you like your inappropriate obnoxious uncle... he's stupid and makes cheesy jokes, but you can't help but to laugh. There's something really charming and genuine about Sandler that keeps you coming back for more.I will say this was better than I was expecting, and the tribute to Chris Farley definitely got me choked up.

When I saw it on the Netflix, honestly I wasn't so sure about going for it considering Sandler's not-enough-enjoyable works during the recent years. However, reviews here convinced me to give it a go, and, well, was definitely worth it!The show basically consists of songs and jokes. The jokes are alright, but the songs, omg the songs! You just have to hear them, just give it a go.
Is really nice having a good laugh with adam, and he make cry a little with the CF song, I think he was amazing too
Laughed at virtually every joke and song, and even cried during a couple of touching tributes. 10+++++++ stars.
He made me laugh, he made me cry. Adam Sandler gave me all the feels with this special. It was real and from his heart, but goofy, hilarious, witty, and nostalgic. I loved every moment of it.

Eddie is a classic in this movie. I just finished watching it and i laughed all the way through. Sometimes controversial, but always truthful. Please watch, you will be satisfied if you need some major laughs. Im bout to go watch it again. I like that he is not afraid to talk about "sensitive" subjects. "yup, the preacher did it", that line had me dying laughing. This is one of the best stand up movies I've seen in a long time. I think Eddie had a lot of revelation happen in his life, and he's freely sharing it in Oakland that night. Oh and at the end credits Eddie gets down for a minute to show he ain't no punk with the dancing.

Granted I haven't really been a fanboy here, but I have watched some of Jim Jefferies previous shows, and yes I have been quite amused by those. So when I found this 2018 "This Is Me Now" on Netflix, I did of course give it a chance.Well, I must start right off by saying that the spark is fading. This show was nowhere near his previous shows in intensity, in humor, in stage presence, or even in enjoyment. It felt like he was running on auto-pilot and was doing a half-hearted attempt at delivering jokes based on material which wasn't all that funny to begin with.I was only laughing twice throughout the entire show. Those times was during the scene with the son and the toilet, and the second time was with the Al Pacino segment.Aside from that, then this was a very bland experience. And I must admit that I was actually sitting with my phone and playing Uno on Facebook during the show, and just listening to him stumble about on the stage. Yeah, the show had that little appeal.

7/16/18. While he was funny in parts, he has an extremely big potty mouth. I just find that kind of language offensive and lazy. One can express oneself well without resorting to foul language. Near the end he reveals that he has been dealing with depression almost his whole life. Ok, that explains some things. Watch only if you are into potty mouth humor.

I'm a big Jim Jefferies fan and I've seen maybe all his stand up and this one is probably the worst. It's a little too political at times which to me is fine if it lands but a lot of the jokes didn't land. I'm glad I stuck around though as he had a great bit about Al Pacino though that was worth the wait and makes me question if he actually met him. I'm sure he hasn't but he did the impersonation so good.

I really liked the first couple of Jim Jefferies stand-up specials, he was a fresh, edgy and rambunctious new voice when he first appeared, but living in LA and hosting that awful chat-show seems to have tamed him and given him no time to come up with any quality material. He really doesn't have anything new to say and what he does have to say isn't all that funny. There are no great set-pieces or even any lines you'd want to remember to pass on to anyone else. I laughed precisely twice. Some of the bit about Trump was moderately amusing but so safe and predictable, and nothing that the average man in the street couldn't have easily come up with himself. The Al Pacino story was nice but didn't lead anywhere, or add up to anything, it was just some stuff that happened. Unless it was simply a contractual obligation, I can't actually see why Jefferies wanted to put this show out at all. Really just a disappointment.

This is a representation of how California can ruin the quality of a comedian through Hollywood and L.A.'s political correctness from far leftists. Jim lost his edge and started making recycled jokes in this This Is Me Now. He said the word contract in this show, and other comedians that started to decrease their quality for Netflix have said the same word. Is it an indicator of a potentially bad show for all comedians now? Also, Jim has talked about how his audience paid for his show just like the other comedians who have decreased their quality for Netflix have. Is that another indicator of a potentially bad show for all comedians now? Should I just switch to another comedian if a comedian says their audience paid for their show and says the word contract in their show because those 2 things are indicators that their show will suck? Besides all of that, this show really disappointed me and made me think Jim being sentimental about his depression was too much for me to take. He needs to get some help and maybe when he does his shows will be better. I think because of his breakup with his girlfriend, his depression before that relationship I mentioned started, and his involvement in L.A. have all messed with his quality of comedy.

Sooo the good thing is Jim still does specials.. I thought he would pursue TV/film career more by now but he is still true to his roots. Or at least he's trying... The show was good overall but lacked a spark of sorts.. a mojo, if you will.. Jim just seemed to have lost the passion for the topics he talked about. I understand it is harder for him to find the zeal maybe partially due to the Jim Jefferies show where he just has to sift through a horrible amount of information and news and try and pick the most interesting or funny ones. How much involved in the production of the JJ show he is, I do not know, but it seems to wear him down a bit. Jim just doesn't seem like the day in, day out working kind of guy...

I haven't laughed this hard in a long time. Jim Jefferies really knows how to a tell a story with a super funny ending. Reminds me of Eddie Murphy and Richard Pryor who also had me laughing so hard it hurt. He says it like it is. No holds barred. That's what I like. But you may not... That's just how it works with opinions.

Do me a favor and work something funny next time. Maybe Work a bit before act, not just drink and think you're funny. Thank god I'm not one of those sorry people who had pay to sit and wait for a plasure night.. ..and didnt get it.

I watched this on my computer and after like 25 minutes I moved it to my 2nd monitor and decided to do something else primarily. The jokes are okayish, but not very original. There wasn't a single moment where I actually laughed or, you now, exhaled air through my nose loudly. I watched his TV show exactly once and turned it off after 10 minutes. It was pure garbage, non-funny and nowhere near the old Jim stuff. Of course there is a difference between a stand up and a weekly show (is it weekly? no idea). But then again he has writers for that show. Anyways, he seems more tame, maybe life wore him down. Maybe he has to do specials, but doesn't really want to. Because I knew the part, I knew he would pretend to be a director, I knew his agent would jump in etc. Maybe he told this in some YouTube video, but that must've been at least 4-6 months old, because I didn't really watch any Jim stuff recently.Overall it was a 4/10, but he is still likable, so 5/10
I've witnessed funnier tax returns.Jim really missed the mark with this one. Skip this and head straight to an actual comedian, like Ricky Gervais.
Jeff Erie's was at one time extremely funny and talented. He has gone from that to what we see now, a has been. His comedy has become lazy and unoriginal. So sad. He once was a great comedian.

I've been a fan of Jim jefferies long before he became an American political sheep. I love all his old stand ups and his legit tv shows. All so fresh and unpolitically correct. Since freedumb, which I did like a bit, I started seeing the change in him. And his latest tv show, which I stopped watching after s01e04, I can see why his new special is called this is me now. I even signed up to imdb and gave my first ever review just to let you, and all your fans of old, know just how disappointing an unknown Australian comedian has become corrupted by popular American media and fame. Jim is funny as always, but the stories are so long, funny and well connected that it's just unbeleivable. Can't really understand why there's so many bad reviews.
He used to be good. Very cutting edge comedy. Now, he's all political, jump on Trump, low hanging fruit comedy. So sad to see him catering to Hollywood mindset.
Pretty good, not so sharp like previous special but still enjoyed!

Unfortunately, you should just watch one of Jim's earlier specials which are better. This special is basically just a rehash of all his old jokes, telling a new audience about old jokes he told at his other shows. Nothing new, i turned it off. It's boring and not funny.
His other Netflix specials are amazing, by comparison this one is just boring and his delivery feels like he knows it's average and just going through the motions.

This was a first for me. I never heard of Sebastian Maniscalco before so I didn't really know what to expect. I like discovering new stand-up comedians that make me laugh and he's one of them. His material wasn't bad at all, I laughed for almost the entire show, but his stage presence is certainly as good as his jokes. He's all over the place, very expressive and mimical, and that was a positive part of the show. Some good comedians just bring their jokes in a static way, he's the complete opposite. I like both genres as long as the jokes are good, but to be honest if I had to choose I prefer a more active stage presence, and Sebastian Maniscalco does that perfectly well.

Because it's hilarious and his newer specials are sadly not as funny.But this one was so refreshing, his delivery, stories and confidence were super fresh. It's not your average beta male comedian with self-pitying cringy humor - this fella is confident and I really liked seeing a male comedian act like this for once.Overall a definitely must see comedy special. He's got the combined presense of Brian Regan and Bill Burr, which is a win. But of course - his own unique and fantastic delivery.

We opened our doors to everyone in the 80's. I remember my mom buying encyclopedias this way. Nowadays, I look at my camera app to see who's at the door. I tell my kids never ever go to the door. I might take 4 steps down stairs to look at the front door, but not a 5th because I know from the front door view they will see my foot if I'm on that 5th step. In this modern world, we don't get company anymore, just solicitors. And when friends come over, they do exactly what SM talked about, they text... "We are here," or "turning on Grand ave. be there in 1 minute." LOL! Nobody you know rings on doorbells anymore, it's all solicitors.
Sebastian is by far the best stand up comedian. Luckily I get to listen to The Pete and Sebastian show every week because I have worn out all Sebastian's stand up specials!

I watch a lot of stand up comedy, and I chuckle at most and even have a few good laughs along the way. But this is my first time watching Sebastian Maniscalco, and I laughed out loud more times in this hour than I usually do in a half dozen other standups combined. At one point I laughed so hard I think I had a little accident.This guy makes everything funny. Sure, he talks about his wife and domestic situations, and maybe that's not so unusual in itself. But the way he does it is unique, and his macho Italian persona's reactions to the idiosyncrasies of humanity is priceless. His expressions, his timing, his wild gestures, give the jokes a life that other comics' routines can't touch. Maniscalco is a veritable artist of comedy .. you can't help but laugh the entire hour. Now I have to watch everything I can on this guy.

This special is so funny that I can almost say it word for word. (I was going to use the word "recite" but don't know how to spell the word and don't want to open up a google) I will text people in the middle of the night to see if they have watched the special yet and immediately send a second text before they respond saying..."I know you haven't watched yet because I haven't received a Thank You text from you. Get on your and click the Flix." Keep up the good work Sebastian!

"Rob Schneider: Asian Momma, Mexican Kids" wasn't really all that funny.That is essentially all that is needed said about this 2020 stand-up comedy show from Rob Schneider. For some reason, then I am liking his comedic acts a lot more in the movie, than I am enjoying him standing on stage and attempting to be funny.Truth be told, then I laughed only twice during this 2020 show. So for comedy value, then "Rob Schneider: Asian Momma, Mexican Kids" was a bit of a lacking experience, and there are far better and more funny shows readily available, if you enjoy stand-up comedy.I will say that Rob Schneider does have some good things in the show, and he delivers his material well enough. But the guy is just lacking energy and on-stage-presence. He just feels like a shadow milling about on the stage telling jokes that are more-often-than-not less than funny.I am rating "Rob Schneider: Asian Momma, Mexican Kids" a four out of ten stars. While it was watchable, it was hardly a laugh-fest, and it definitely is not a show that I will be watching a second time, because there just wasn't enough funny material in the show.

You're sitting there and you just KNOW somethings going to happen and you'll laugh and you wait and wait and the suspense builds because you just KNOW Rob's going to say something funny and OMG here it comes and...NOTHING. Again and again. Nothing. He's lost it. Does have a cute family, though.

In the 90's Rob Schnieder was one of the funniest people alive. Men Behaving Badly was awesome, and he killed it on Saturday night live. I was so excited to see that he was making at least some form of a comeback with this special. Sadly, the magic isn't there. Sure there are a few funny one-liners, but overall, it just feels hollow and empty.
This is simply story-time about his latest wife and his kids and his youth and mother and a few other things that are not all that funny.
The piano player was really unnecessary👎.Not bad but could be much faster. I believe he is done.

I'm not the biggest fan of Rob Schneider. I like some of his stuff, couple of movies but overall I always though he pushed the comedy a little too hard and litlle on the nose. In this special though he feels very natural an relaxed, toned down and almost likeable. Some jokes were predictable but many weren't and I had some good laughs. I would ditch the piano player and the Roy Orbison impersonation feat. Elle King, or what was that suposed to be..? Overall a pleasant surprise though..
He had no energy, none of his usual charisma. Outdated and old material, a few laughs but painfully bland most of the time. Definitely not worth watching. Such a shame.

I was lucky to catch this show when it was filmed in Salt Lake City. It was way more funny (and delightfully raunchy) than I expected, and made me a fan of Schneider's. And I'll be honest: I never much liked Rob Schneider and thought he was kind of a no-talent, but came to the performance because we like going to the theater.
It's hilarious, I couldn't stop laughing As a fan of rob Schneider it's nice to see some of his stand up comedy and it's some of the best

I laughed so many times. His voices are great, the inclusion of his family is charming & sweet. His jokes are relatable & clever. I created this IMDb account just so I can write a good review. If you want to have a light hearted laugh with your partner or friends, this show fits the bill. And the duet at the end with Elle King is really magnificent. You see their genuine joy in being together, you can feel how much they love & cherish their family, and the song is touching. And wowww what an amazing singer Elle King is.

My husband and I just got done watching Rob Schneider's comedy's special on Netflix and we were laughing so hard, I thought we woke our daughter a couple of times. I even had to pause it the special so we wouldn't miss what he was saying next, because Rob had us in tears.
