Rock would only spend 3 years at SNL before heading off on his own, eventually reinventing himself as a prominent name in stand-up. He had released an album, Born Suspect, while still a cast member of SNL, and enjoyed some success with his HBO debut, the half-hour special Big Ass Jokes, but his success was limited. However, there was a buzz coming into this night, with a captive crowd just waiting for Rock to deliver big. It's an expectation seemingly shared by Rock, himself. Right off the bat, album covers from stand-up greats (Bill Cosby, Dick Gregory, Flip Wilson (as Geraldine), Richard Pryor, Steve Martin, Pigmeat Markham, Woody Allen and Eddie Murphy) are overlayed on footage of Rock making his way to the stage. Easing in with some material directed to his audience in Washington, Rock takes some jabs at Marion Barry (Note for the kids out there: He's kind of like the black Rob Ford) participating in the Million Man March festivities, which then leads him into a nice little run on crack that easily reels in the audience. From there, he explores politics, prisons, and the OJ Simpson trial before going into his views on the divide in the black community, highlighting the polarizing ways some in the community carry themselves, and unafraid to turn that spotlight inward with some keen criticisms. Once he's done covering these themes, Rock settles in and spends the last 15-20 minutes of his time exploring relationships between men and women, his charisma actually winning women over while he's pointing out their flaws. This isn't surprising as there aren't many who aren't won over by his million-dollar smile. This set turned Rock into a superstar, and it's easy to see why. Years later, it still seems vibrant and vital. Many would go on to emulate his style, but few ever made it work like he did.

Chris Rock's Bring the Pain may be the funniest stand-up comedy I have ever had the pleasure of experiencing. The barbs are excrutiatingly accurate, raunchy, and hilarious, and are (no kidding) extraordinarily thought-provoking.Just so you know where my commentary is coming from, I am a 40 year old, white, middle-class male from Houston, Texas. I have seen Rock's talk show on HBO, and haven't really cared for it. I thought he was reasonably entertaining on Saturday Night Live, but nothing spectacular. When it comes to stand-up comedy, I'm a big fan of circa 1978 Steve Martin stand-up (Wild and Crazy Guy) and I love Seinfeld's 'I'm Telling You for the Last Time'. Do yourself a favor, rent/buy 'Bring the Pain' and prepare yourself for some mind-blowing, prejudice-shattering, side-splitting hilarity.
The very best stand up set of the 90s. Dominant, fast paced and supremely hilarious.

I wasn't a Chris Rock fan until I saw this show. I'd catch just a few moments of the show while channel surfing, and didn't think much of it. One night, out of boredom I watched a few minutes of his material and was floored. I couldn't believe how funny he was. On further airings I caught the complete show, and discovered his humour also contained cutting social insights which added to the humor.

What does this mean? Does Chris Rock make black people less intimidating to whites simply because he points out their weakness? Last time I saw "Live at the Appolo" on TV, all I saw was a lot of crotch-grabbing and swagger and not much thought-provoking thoughts like Chris Rock presents in this show. If your black, laugh at yourself. If your white, laugh too, but realize it's your everyday actions that "Bring the Pain."

*bows*All hail Chris Rock, one of the finest stand-up comedians I have ever seen."Bring The Pain" is simply amazing, a total riot from start to finish. Chris Rock discusses life, relationships, racism, society, politics, and controversial figures such as OJ Simpson, Marion Barry, and even the President -- speaking not only from personal experience but also keen observations. You will laugh your arse off -- he's witty, insightful, sagacious, and always brutally honest.If you want to see a true master of his art, go rent Chris Rock's DVD "Never Scared" (which contains "Bring The Pain"). Oh, and a word to the wise; don't try to eat or drink near punchlines. You *will* get coke up your nose and/or choke. This nearly happened to me during the scene where he talks about Martin Luther King -- one of my favorites, not only because it's hysterical, but also because it's a shining example of his perceptiveness.So go watch it! ;) - Kate

This was the third stand-up comedy I watched from Demetri martin. After Live (At the Time) from 2017 and Standup Comedian from 2012, both shows that were very enjoyable, it was time for The Overthinker this time. A perfect title to resume Demetri Martins mind. He thinks a lot about things nobody thinks about and that's what we like about him. His jokes are well thought of, most of the time obvious but only he thought about them. He's a natural to bring his one-liners, they all work. His drawings are also very funny, very basic as a drawing but certainly funny as comedy. This show is what we are basically used of him by now, it still works (at least to me), and I'm already looking forward to his next show. Demetri Martin never disappoints, he's an excellent entertainer.

I Love Stand up Comedy and the reason why I give him a 10 out of 10. Is his Difference bettween alot of other Stand ups. His Music, his Art Work, his Comedy is alot more different then most. He is a very smart man. Love his work it is also pretty funny.
Demetri's humor is incentive, clever and always a delight. There's not another like him.

Demitri Martin is a talented comedian, no argue about that. His strong side is making intelligent observations about life, Wich doesn't always have a big response on people. I mean, I did laugh several times during The Overthinker, but most of my appreciation comes by the good points he makes. As I said on the title, he doesn't make sex jokes, and I appreciate that, cause his jokes are mostly family friendly, and that's very rare on comedians...
Good funny jokes and defiantly worthy of the time but the last comedian doing that type of show was Rodney Dangerfield. Now a great stand up routine needs a little more cohesion.
I was laughing pretty much the whole time, what more can you ask for? :)
I love the drawings. Some of the jokes arent Superb, but, eh, Its still a pretty good comedy special.

What happened? Demitri's standup used to be sweet, clever and relatively clean. This is sweary, lazy, undeveloped and embarrassing. Literally admitting onstage that you have no ending to a joke... come on. So disappointed.

Demetri Martin has made me laugh in the past. He's made me laugh with the same jokes as the ones at the beginning of this special! The foundation of his comedy is the twists of concepts so when they're the same as previous work it's like dead air. Going to watch one more of his specials because of benefit of the doubt: Netflix could have told him "we need to show the new audience the jokes we've heard"

A strange artefact this, from the odd period just before Stewart Lee became absolutely enormous in the late noughties and one of Britain's most lauded art comedians of all time - but here he's off the back of a failed DVD ("Stand-Up Comedian") and a botched musical that got him in serious legal trouble and wondering where he fits into it all. Filmed in a small arts venue in Cardiff and fairly smartly welded together from two different sets it's raw, caustic and contains the skeleton of what he would later build up to be "his schtick". That being sort of blistering self-awareness and a slow and clever build to a sort of semi-breakdown-as-comedy catharsis. It still shines brightly, all these years later, and there's a wild clarity here that frankly only a protracted vomiting session can truly produce.

I try to watch a stand-up comedy per day, preferably of comedians I don't know yet, just too be surprised or not. So this was the first show I watched from Chris D'Elia and to be honest I wasn't impressed at all. It looked and sounded like he had more fun with his jokes than me. He has an irritating laugh that he uses after almost all of his puns. Also the Yeahs, Yos, Heys and so on, at one point it's getting boring. Too much repetitive jokes and not so funny jokes, after a while I got really bored hearing those. But it worked for the audience, that seemed to have fun, so I guess there are people finding his show funny, unfortunately I wasn't one of them. I'm probably not going to watch other shows from him, for that there are so much more comedians that I love or that I still have to discover.
Daniel Tosh is really funny in this special. It is his first. I think his later specials are more focused and even funnier, but this one is great too.I laughed all the way through this one.

Daniel Tosh is my new favorite comedian. I saw this special on Comedy Central when it first came out and I loved it so much that I decided to buy the DVD. It's seriously one of the funniest and most clever specials I've seen so far. I'm a big fan of guys like Jim Gaffigan, Brian Regan, Lewis Black, Mitch Hedburg and most of the Comedt Central comedians but I think Daniel Tosh may be the best. He has hilarious jokes about Kobe Bryant, wave runners, Survivor, and many, many more. If you're comedy fan, you owe it to yourself to see the piece of comedy gold. You will most likely love everything about it and enjoy it for years and years to come. Go pick up the DVD!

It's far from the most consistent standup special I've seen, and it took me a little while to get into it, but once I settled in it was genuinely very funny. I'm not hugely familiar with The Eric Andre Show, but had seen enough clips to more or less know what I was in for with an Eric Andre standup special. It could've easily gone on a little longer, because 50-something minutes is a bit on the short side, but if you're a fan of his sense of humour I can't see why you wouldn't get something out of this show. (Also the fact he did voice work in a Disney movie makes some of the cruder jokes here extra funny, but I don't know if that's just me.)
He's very high strung and stressful to watch... Its not funny even though i love coke myself... Just had to turn it off..

But this special is just full of observational humor and hard drugs jokes.20 minutes of here's a story about weed, now here's a story about coke, now here's a story about LSD, here's a story about when i did Xanax. The jokes are alright but people just laugh their ass off cause he screams all the punchlines like a maniac.When he tries to go deeper political or whatever it dosen't really land. For me anyway.Loved the prank movie he just did and of course the Eric Andre show but honestly i didn't really laugh here. But stand up is subjective so i'm just telling my experience.I'm older, my drug experimenting days are over so i think maybe it's gonna please the younger crowd more than me.

It has some funny parts but mostly is just him exaggerating everything and unlike his show is not random enough to make it funny, it's just awkward. His Adult Swim Commencement speech on youtube is 6 minutes long and its 1000 times funnier. Love Eric Andre but he looks like he just snorted cocaine and improvised everything on stage and it's pretty terrible unfortunately.
Not every joke lands, but the ones that do make it worth a watch

As a fan of Eric's I have watched most of his stand ups. There were a few jokes I had noticed that were recycled which is fine for the people that never had watched him before. For fans of his however, this was a bit disappointing.With him going political throughout his standup I could see why he would based off of the title "legalize everything" but some of the political stances should've just been left out but not to say they weren't fair points to be made they just weren't fluid I felt with the whole premise.Eric is known to be goofy and just all over the place which is what it was at the beginning, but it felt like towards the end of the show he was giving up. The phone call at the end with one of the viewers mother on their phone felt a bit scripted and not organic at all but hey I guess that's just part of the act to make it lighthearted and funny to close the show on.All in all I wouldn't say I would recommend watching this although I would recommend watching The Eric Andre Show because that show is hilarious and honestly throughout the whole standup I maybe had laugh only once.
Absolutely one of a kind dude that gives zero _____s. So glad I found this comedic genius can't wait to finish watching more of the eric andre show. Bravo sir, you're comedy gold.
If you have watched his show and are upset that all he does is shout then I'm not sure what you are doing here. Yes it's hard to watch, he is known for cringe comedy.
All of the "punchlines" are just yelling, and it isn't fun.

There are some seriously boring people in this world, imagine voting 1 out of 10 for this. Anyway, ignore the uptight people with no sense of humour that hate their lives and give it a watch. It was hysterical.
A child who has just learned a new bad word screams it on a stage for an hour.Aggressively unfunny edgelord embarasses himself while randomly groping public.
This is an exceptional special. It's so intelligent that you need three degrees to understand it. Do you have three degrees? That's probably why you don't understand it.

Yes, he's loud. Yes, he's on about being on something... and, seemingly on something. And it's definitely on the nose (the comedy, not the coke) and sometimes in your face with the yelling.But I found it all rather amusing. I'm not a drug user at all, I don't even drink or like the premise. And, gosh, this man loves it all.But, he was sufficiently entertaining at the end of a night in, while not paying 100% attention but still watching most of it. Likeable dude, a little annoying yet enjoyable performance, funny jokes and there's meaning to a lot of it.

I know, that's kinda his schtick. And at a few occasions he really did make me laugh out loud but is is not enough when most of the time the jokes were predictable or/and just downright cringeworthy. Being loud doesn't always make something funnier, far from it.
It is either he is lying or he is a criminal. Taking all these drugs is illegal. Normalizing cocaine and addiction is not funny.

I sympathise with the reviewers who say this special was plainly unfunny; I felt the same around ten minutes in. Notwithstanding, Eric Andre did make a few genuinely funny jokes, the brunt of which was enough to keep me through until the end. A lot of it is, however, just Eric screaming, which gets annoying quickly. Most of my enjoyment for the special stemmed from watching Eric's mannerisms, detached from what he says; he is a legitimately crazy person. All this said, Eric was never meant to be a stand-up comedian, and though I did enjoy the show, it wasn't because he's a good comic; it's because he is actually insane.

I love the Eric Andre Show but this wasn't my cup of tea. I'm not really the biggest fan of these Netflix comedy specials and I felt that this one was pretty average. There's none of the outlandish humor Eric Andre is known for and this felt quite juvenile even for Eric Andre's standards. If you're a fan of the show I can't say you'd like this that much. If you enjoy being bombarded with jokes about weed and lsd, I'm sure you'd enjoy.

I really was disappointed by this. Eric Andre's outlandish style should be stamped all of this thing but this is just a standard Netflix comedy special. It's watchable if you like jokes about drugs but for fans of the show, you'll be sorely disappointed if you expect anything like it. I exhaled a little bit out of my nose a few times but I thought it was unfunny for the most part.

I like Eric Andre and so far enjoyed everything I've seen from him...but what the hell was this supposed to be? If all the "hey guys, weed is awesome, amirite???" crowd work was meant to be an ironic take on douche-bro spring-break stand-up, it was lost on me. Maybe it was the room? The audience did look and feel very young, drunk, and rowdy, and quite low-brow, so maybe Eric had to adjust his style for the night, but then why did he use this footage for his Netflix special?But the earnest, laboured low-brow-comedy wasn't the worst part - that was when Eric decided to do some scripted / staged FaceTime call to someone's mum who was surprisingly unsurprised and played along a little too "yes-and-y" to be believable. It was clearly a scripted bit which Eric tried to sell as unscripted - which in itself is a thing Eric has satirised and mocked on his show over and over again.To see him become something that I thought he'd reject and dislike based on his earlier work was almost a bit shocking.Let's hope this was a one-time slip-up.
I laughed through the whole thing and I'm an entirely sober person. It borderlines on surreal at times, this may be one of Netflix's best stand up specials.

This special felt like an extended monologue from his television show. There were some good jokes, a funny opening skit, and a funny unscripted ending but a lot of the jokes in the first half felt like rejected bits that only served to alienate people who aren't used to his type of humor. The viewer needs to go in expecting unorthodox and weird.
Not even the fans at his show seem to be liking his jokes
He is on coke on this special. Too much energy is a big turnoff
Tbh my only complaint was the last 3 seconds. he's funny though.

Eric Andre was very much needed during quarantine! This special is honest, funny and obviously, full of adult content very much like his show. Stuff you'd secretly laugh to are all in here. People saying that this is childish gotta take a break and enjoy.

It's on youtube, so it's convenient and cheap. But don't let that be the deciding factor. It's as good as any special on Netflix, etc. right now - and a WHOLE lot better than many of the specials that have been put out by people who are clearly not actual comedians. I don't want to name names but Hannah Gadsby, Eric Andre, Ilana Glazer, Adam Devine and many others come to mind. He's a bit story-telling and a quick pace which will keep you laughing. Just watch it. WATCH IT!
One of the real comedians without recognition, should be more known
Love Joe List. Love this special. One of the best specials to come out in 2020, in my opinion. I'm really happy it was free on YouTube, but I would gladly pay money for it.

I just ran the four current positive reviews though our schools plagiarism detection suite and it flags then as virtual certainty same author using sentence structure analysis. No surprising since you have the one first review (probably someone associated the production) and then the other three are all single use accounts created solely to shill this up. IMDBPro shows that beyond the reviews, the other metric, the positive user ratings are all single use accounts Ironically this repetition is actually the major problem with the Normand strand-up routine. I promise you -- you have heard versions every joke in it, and it is essentially a groan fest.
Just because the title says Amy Schumer They are blindly giving it one star rating. Amy Schumer is just the producer, Mark Normand is doing the stand up.

Mark Normand is a quick, smart and thoughtful comedian. His fast style comedy is composed mostly of set up followed by joke; It's clean and extremely precise. You can still see that Mark sometimes is not confortable with silence, because even after brilliantly well written jokes he rushes to the next one; unfortunately giving no wiggle room for the joke pack a bigger punch. Personally, his style kinda remminds me of some bits of young of Louis CK on tv, but a little bit more awkward. Just know you're in for a treat.
I'm a big stand up fan, and am aware of the amy schumer stuff. which has to be why this is rated so horribly. If you enjoy stand up, i urge you to give it a shot.

I've been on a hunt for a new standup comic and I'm a comedy enthusiast. Mark normand is exceptional in his ability to portray himself as a laid back guy with a certain unrequited charm about him.. I promise you won't regret watching his standup. And i went through the entire process of registration and confirmation just so i can rate this guy a perfect ten. Believe me you won't regret it..

Are you easily offende? Do you consider yourself someone not able to laugh at absurdities of life and circumstances but rather being a fighter for what is right and good? And I am seriously asking, because this may not be something you want to watch if that is the case.Now the special drew big controversy because of one topic/subject matter. And Dave I would say was fully aware of it. Because it's not like he is not using language and making jokes right from the start. Some may feel attacked by those - like when he mixes serious things that happened and still happen - violence against Asians has risen for example due to the Corona Virus "origin" ... he makes a joke about his body and his immune system, that some may consider borderline racist and fueling anti-vaxxers and their desperate "fight".But that is what I (and of course many others as is evident by the rating here) consider the genius of Dave Chappelle! He really does not shy away from taking punches - but he also gets emotional. He is a human and he is openly admitting on being flawed. When he calls himself a ...phobic or tells us what he did at a certain time ... realizing himself it was not the best choice to make ... that's human. And all the while he is able to make us laugh - but also care. Not just for him, but others. He makes it his fight to show certain things in society - he doesn't claim to have the solution for any of it - but it sure is important to point things out.Going against "wokeness" is not a bad thing in my book. But it is a "dangerous" thing with people being cancelled left and right. Well certain people deserve it, but with the outrage machine impossible to stop, there will be victims too. Just the fact that I point this out will upset people. The fact of the matter is, that whatever you say, someone will be offended. You're either too nice or too aggressive or something else. You should always be true to yourself, while also acknowleding and respecting others and their feelings of course. But that is a journey and we all should be allowed to make mistakes.So while this is a dope comedy special (I hope the word dope is still being used), it is also a mirror to society in many respects. And ends with a story that is uplifting, devestating, exhilarating and somewhat hopeful alltogether. Now that is quite the amazing accomplishment.

Right up front, I'm not a Dave Chappelle fan and have not seen any of his prior work. I would not have watched this Netflix special if the current controversy surrounding it were more muted. Having seen it, I'm not sure whether I'd go back to watch any of his other stand-up routines. But here's the thing. The guy had something to say, and he came out and said it. You can call it misogynistic or gay bashing or transphobic, but in the current climate of woke culture, what he's saying needed to be said. And not only that, but to be heard, which is more of an issue I think, than accusing the guy of things that he is not. He backs up everything he talked about with real life examples in which he had to confront hostile or negative people responding to his brand of humor. And even when he spells it out in plain English, you still have folks who either intentionally misinterpret or downright refuse to accept what he has to say. I'm not going to proclaim him some kind of hero for 'The Closer', but I think it took at least a small amount of courage to present this show the way he did. In the end, I think he offered some pretty profound stuff in his own inimitable fashion, and all you have to do is take a breath and listen.

A Netflix-produced special, capturing a Dave Chappelle stand-up comedy routine in Detroit.Continuing in the series of Netflix-produced comedy specials by Dave Chappelle, this instalment is very similar in content, quality and vibe to what came before. Funny, irreverent, subversive and distinctly un-PC but if you know Dave Chappelle's style of comedy, you know that's what you're going to get.Not as funny as Chappelle's Show or his earlier stuff in general though. While still very edgy and un-PC, his earlier stuff was a bit more sophisticated and better-developed and the punchlines were more powerful. His early stuff was off-the-charts brilliant though so a bit unfair to compare this to that. In addition, being a long-time Chappelle fan, the novelty has probably worn off a bit for me and I know what to expect.

Dave Chappelle doing it as only Dave Chappelle can. In this special, which he forecasts as his last, he lets the jokes fly and leaves a trail of cancelists in his wake. He took aim at the alphabet community with specific advice for the T's. It wasn't as malicious as it was observant and advisory. It was funny, it was poignant, it was classic Chappelle.

The show started a bit slow, with some jokes that, Chappelle style, were trying to ostensibly offend in a humorous way but also set up something. I didn't know what he was trying to set up, I didn't know what he was trying to say, but I distinctly thought to myself: has anyone hugged Dave lately? The man needs a hug. And I didn't know why, I just knew that he had real pain on his face - and I am the guy who couldn't care less about the feelings of others most of the time, so that is saying something.Before he started talking about Daphne, he talked about how annoying he found people who were judging him based on a famous piece on him, using the same lingo and addressing only the talking points in that article, and I felt a little awkward because I hadn't watched The Closer for a while just because of the various news items about people hating on Chappelle or him going too far against the trans people and so on. I didn't really need the aggravation, you see, I wanted to feel safe. But it hit me that I was watching the show with some preconceptions already formed, and not formed voluntarily. I was waiting for the scathing jokes about trans people, the offensive words, the heartless comments, curious if I will feel he went too far or laugh my ass off.And what I got was the opposite of that: a thoughtful, soulful, emotional and honest piece about what it means to be human. I can't imagine the kind of deranged people that would get offended at this show - though remember most psychopaths are not smart at all - yet I can understand why the outragey Twitterati posing as one minority or another to do their evil would be afraid of The Closer. It was setting up universal empathy and did it well.Bottom line: I think it was an amazing show, a rollercoaster of emotion and thought, something that people need to see and experience for themselves.

Dave Chappelle: The Closer(2021) is a standup routine from the legend himself currently available on Netflix. My wife and I watched this, like every Chapelle standup, and he always tackles current events, recent headlines about himself, misconceptions, and everything is spoke on unapologetically. There's some great topics in here about the LGBTQ backlash he's recently received, the pandemic and where he is in his career. There's definitely some laugh out loud moments but this isn't as hilarious as some previous stand ups and probably doesn't tackle as big of issues as he has historically (8:46). Overall this is still an absolute must see but far from his best show. I'd score this a solid 7/10.

In this era of cancel culture and intersectionality Dave Chappelle is in an enviable position as a Black male hovering at the top of this sacred cow list. In his latest stand-up he uses this cachet to comically expound on transgenderism much to the chagrin of the easily offended. Chappelle also takes shots at whites in Michigan and Mike Pence (an amazingly Trump free stand-up) but that is standard fare targeting a group with big shoulders, use to the ribbing. Transgenders are another story however who brook no criticism and this may be a watershed moment with Chappelle having the nerve to play no favorites, declaring his right to say as he pleases as a humorist. The show does have some slow moments but they remain blips in this mostly funny stand-up that should have reverberations in the days ahead, pitting two intersectional titans against each other.
This is different. It's not extremely funny. It's Dave saying things that he personally needed to say.

This is really more of a raconteur at work that pure stand up. It's funny, but he has a point and wants to make it clear. He circles around it multiple times, and brings you where he wants you to be. Some people may be offended, but thats hardly an indictment, people are offended by almost everything now. A strong hour overall.

Dave Chappelle won the Mark Twain Award for humor a couple of years ago, and this is what his show is all about. Chappelle makes many funny jokes, and remarks, but he also makes a lot of personal points that tie in with humor. It is more than comedy, it is thoughtful humor.I have watched many Dave Chappelle specials, and his famous TV series. I really appreciated hearing why, how, and what Dave thinks about many of the issues that have been part of his comedy career. I got a sense that for the first time I knew Dave Chappelle, the human being, not just the comedian. Thanks Dave!

A finale of sorts to Chappelle's latest run of Netflix specials. Much of it deals with the controversy that his previous specials have caused, and as a response, contextualisation, and a request for some empathy and understanding, I think it mostly works.I can kind of see both sides (and it's not a clash I'm personally invested in), but maybe some of my lack of passion for one side comes from just being confused and exhausted about the extent and pervasiveness of the Chappelle-related controversy to begin with.The balance of comedy and more serious aspects is pulled off mostly well, but not flawlessly. I will say the last 20 minutes - when the serious stuff gets more prominent and there might be a few less jokes - comprise the strongest part of the special.I don't think any of Chappelle's Netflix specials reach the heights of his early 2000s work (Killin' Them Softly in particular is one of the funniest standup specials of all time), but his style's mellowed out a little bit and he's become more interested in blending comedy with commentary, which has made him one of the more interesting comedians working today.The Closer is a good (though maybe not quite great) finale to a good run of specials, and even if he has a break for a while, I hope this isn't the last we see of Chappelle on stage.

As I said in a review in his previous Netflix standup, Chappelle is the smartest and funniest comedian since George Carlin. He pisses off some groups because he doesn't hold back. He calls out the stupidity and absurdity in politics of the current times just as Carlin did in his time. In time, his comedy will be seen as we see Carlin's today.

This was one of Dave's best stand up skits. I don't want to write anything that can upset anyone, but I think Dave's point is that human experience is what unites people - not unrealistic changes to the rules or double-speak language. The final twenty minutes of this standup is a heartbreaking beautiful and hilarious story about his brief friendship with a trans woman and he does not hold back on his disgust with the way twitter mobs treated his friend. Highly recommended critique of our times.
I didn't think this special was very good. He's too hung up on the Trans jokes and alot just weren't that funny. I had some chuckles here and there but overall I'd say it's the worst of his I'd seen.

I love Dave's comedy, sometimes it doesn't always go as planned but he sure does put in the effort and is daring and creative.This show, however just feels like he's telling stories about his life and past, and only a few are funny. The transgender thing overshadows the entire show and his stories are there to explain his previous actions and it sounds more like an apology than a comedy. If a story isn't funny it's not comedy.I didn't sign up to watch a PBS doc series on LGBT stuff and hopefully he gets this out of his system and can work on actual comedy.

Even if most think they are funny and like a good time laughing, real humor is not for everybody. Laughing about ourselves is not for most humans and we live in a time that every single tweet/joke/phrase offends some people, who don't even try to understand the other side or the goal of a simple joke. People are not ready, people don't want to laugh about themselves.Dave Chappelle is probably the best ever and people who really understand humour will always care and recognise that. This show is more serious than usual on him but with a perfect balance between humor and lessons. He will never be cancelled.

We have admired your comedy for 20 years now. You may not always be understood , but it's clear that your gift remains elevated as you invite us to join you in poking fun at ourselves. As the world hurdles through uncertainty, we can always count on you to stay true to your craft and trust in your intentions. Comedy is a complex form of entertainment, meant to push boundaries and buttons; to give us reason to think , defend , examine evaluate and giggle.For a fan, this is another great Chapelle: intelligent, articulate and real. For anyone just joining in or who is curious, Dave's talent , comedic history and values speak volumes; check out , literally , any of his past work. There is more to him than great comedy specials; his continuing to do stand up speaks to his merit and commitment. The one thing I missed with this special was a less diverse audience,. Yet he takes risks with audiences and their ability to rise.. Quick story , on the worst day of our lives , our grieving family could only agree on one thing "turn on Chapelle anything' we needed a distraction , what we got was laughs and camaraderie. It was sweet relief.Thank you Dave Chapelle.

Dave has always been current, provocative, and funny asf and all in a good way since his days on the Chapelle show.Then in 2020, he got a bit serious and perhaps a bit angrier with a show or two when we needed him the most during the riots, which was a bit of a disappointment to me. I thought he had lost his edge. However, The Closer showed that he didn't lose his edge, but is back in a strong sense with NFG.This was so refreshing to see a comedian talk about whatever topic and not worry if he would get canceled. I hope more people will take notice and speak their minds and truth and not worry about consequences.Definitely a must-watch.

I like Dave Chappelle's brand of comedy, especially The Dave Chappelle show that was on TV from 2003 to 2006 and that was great viewing.Dave Chappelle: The Closer features Dave Chapelle's trademark politically incorrect humour which he is well known for and certainly not for the easily offended.Though he covered segments on racism, gender, identity and cancel culture, half of his show seemed to aim a lot of jokes at the transgender community.Anyone would think his show is transphobic and it certainly hasn't gone down too well with the LGBTIQA+ community, some even calling for his show to be withdrawn from Netflix which won't happen.Dave Chappelle's The Closer did have some funny moments and it passed the time, but overall it's not one of the most memorable shows of Dave Chappelle.It was quite fitting that there was a post credits dedication to fellow comedian Norm Macdonald who passed away on 14 September 2021 aged 61 following a private battle with leukemia.6/10.
Wasn't as funny as the previous special but had some good jokes and just an interestingly well told story. Worth the watch for sure and don't worry about any reviews just trying to tank the rating.

I'm always amazed with Chappelle. He's funny, insightful and says what everyone is afraid to. Because he's not black and white on issues, he's grey. And in these times, that's not easy to do. And it's never easy to do because it requires you to open up and reveal what you really think. And not conform to what your group thinks. To do this you have to be a maverick. And it's not easy.In these times of social media cliques, outrage, oversensitivity and cancel culture to have your own opinion isn't acceptable. Each side wants you to agree without question or else you're the enemy. Well I have my own thoughts and I see the holes in many of these causes. That not everybody that identifies with them is genuine And so does Chappelle. And I agree with almost everything he says. It's nice to see someone else saying it to know that I'm not alone. I'm sure others feel the same way. And that's why we need Dave. He thinks what I think and says it much better than I could and makes it funny. And puts it ways that I could never articulate or think of like him. Dave's a smart guy. He looks at things and questions them. He doesn't close his eyes and repeat what he's supposed to. To think that Dave is transphobic only means one thing: you aren't listening. And that's exactly what's wrong with these days. No one is really listening.So many of us are supportive of everything gay but are confused by the ever changing meanings of definitions and the whole trans thing in general. I don't understand it completely but I do the best I can. No matter what I'll be supportive, because a human is still a human and I'll never discriminate. And there needs to be dialogue between us to help understand. There isn't going to be when the standard is that we can't even ask questions without being branded as the enemy.I question every part of life. They're no different. People shouldn't follow with blind acceptance. You should always think about life and the meanings behind everything for yourself. And Dave is the only one brave enough to do this in public. Every single person I know is accepting but confused. And they're all afraid to bring it up to other's because they don't want to be called a Nazi. When I bring it up to friends they are so happy that they aren't alone with their thoughts. And they are always supportive but confused and it's nice to talk about it to find a better understanding and not feel alone. And why do we usually start talking about this? A Chappelle stand up special.We need people that are brave enough to reflect the voice of people instead of living in this world of fear where everyone is afraid to ask questions to better understand something. Lying about human behavior isn't going to get us anywhere. Repression is never good. Especially out of fear. Let's not forget that straight people are the majority. The trans are the minority. They're even a minority of a minority. The internet would have you believe this is reversed.Not the funniest of his specials but it's not like his jokes fail. It's just not as funny as some others. It's just as good. It's almost not the point to laugh. Dave is talking about real stuff and it's funny along the way.And another thing. Just because one trans person or person from a group says they feel a certain way about something, that doesn't represent the entire group. The internet loves to do this but we all have our own thoughts no matter what race, religion or sex we are.

Holy wank, this is the antichrist to Bo Burnham's holy child.It's been virtually impossible to avoid the discourse surrounding this for the last week, especially seeing as TikTok has been my ADHD app of choice for over a year now, and people are not happy about this. And frankly, if there's anything I find surprising about the controversy, it's that the trans community seems to be the only minority group giving Dave Chappelle some rightfully deserved pushback for this.Because while I know the vast majority of trans people do not appreciate being misgendered, reminded that their genitals aren't what they want them to be, told that they make people uncomfortable in public toilets, or called tr*nnies (even if your dead trans friend was okay with all that, Dave, and yes this does all happen in this), I also know that Asian people do not like being compared to COVID, Jewish people do not like the suggestion that they secretly want to take over the world, and feminists do not like the assumption that they are all "frumpy d*kes"I'm not joking when I say that I now slightly regret criticising Bo Burnham's What for having some jokes that felt a bit edgy, because this trash could have come straight out of the early 2000s and no one would have been the least bit surprised. I have no damn clue what, if any, larger point was being made here, and I laughed one single time, and that was because Chappelle told a joke that someone else made up.And while I'm talking up Bo Burnham yet again, I feel the need to mention that while I don't know whether the "salt and vi..." joke from Make Happy would fly nowadays, you can't deny that it was really goddamn clever, and I'm willing to bet that even if you were offended by it, you at least allowed yourself a little chuckle the first time you saw it. This garbage can't even be clever or amusing, which is the least you could do if you're basically going to center your comedy special on insulting every minority group except your own under the sun in the Western world.So screw this special, and Netflix should be goddamn ashamed that they ever even considered hosting it on their platform, especially - and I really cannot stress this enough - in the same year that Bo Burnham's Inside dropped, which is not just a great comedy special, but one that redefined what a comedy special could be, and is easily my favourite film of the year (if you can call it that), and I really do not expect that to change, either.Meanwhile the only difference between this and the edgy kid telling offensive jokes in your science class back in 2014 is perhaps the worst thing about this, come to think of it: at least the edgy kid is just doing it for attention, and likely doesn't have any delusions of grandeur, the intolerable ego, or notion that he's somehow making some grand statement that just needed to be said like this idiot does.

Its is not so much a comedy show but a conversation of social observation , with a bit of humour .Much of what he says is true and reflects the majority of peoples attitudes .There are funny moments but not laugh out loud .If anything it is a social experiment where Dave knowingly blasts the woke , politically , correct mob in the face with double barrel shotgun of things we are not suppose to talk about .He will catch hell for it by some but in the end thats the genius of it .As a comedy special it lacks laughs. As a political movement commentary it is perhaps the first step in a bigger movement to take back the comedic industry from the woke mob.

People have to stop being offended by anything and everything, because they are frustrated by the pettiness of their boring little lives they will just criticize people like Dave to make themselves feel alive and feel they are important.The world is huge, it doesn't only belong to people from your race, your gender, your line of opinions, etc... accept it.

Just when you think he can't get any better at critiquing society, Dave Chappelle goes and does it. And in fact, he does it better than he ever has before. He talks about everything that we as a society are afraid to discuss, and he says it how it is. No one would dare go wear Dave goes. Everyone must watch this if for no other reason to see the world in a new light.

This stand-up is just a guy yammering about his unfunny life experiences in a plaintive sort of way. There is nothing funny here at all. While he is not repellant he is not endearing either. Maybe he would be good if he had some decent material. Or maybe he got really good after the fifteen minutes I gave him. I will never know.

Was surprised I enjoyed it so much, not that I had low expectations of Seth himself. Due to the barrage of not-so-great Netflix comedy specials; especially the number of ones the include talent who don't normally do standup. This was a rare treat and found myself laughing quite audibly throughout.There was mention (by another review) of the unusual framing of the filmography, but that didn't distract me personally from the general comedic content for too long.
We watched it twice tonight, couldn't stop laughing, was really refreshing and I think we will watch it again soon!!! Great work!
I honestly forgot all about my life troubles and laughed for the entirety of the stand-up. I wish he had more stand-up performances cuz I would watch them all!

Everything is safe and then its a return to his week night routines and then Trump bashing. I am not even American and can see its just taking shots that he takes on his own late night shows. Its the same with all the late show hosts, the only time they do or say anything political is when they see that the crowd is getting bored. Its a safe place and an easy target. Then its back to safety of the plain jokes that every other 99% of the comedians do in their shows. Even when he does the whole fatherhood thing he says that he can't even do that right. Its a boring scripted show taking aim at things that others like him keeping say and its the same boring jokes and laughs, sadly. Was expecting much more. 1 2 3 4 5 6 x10mins and its over.
Great show, just felt the wife bit when a little long.

This gig is like your excited friend telling you all about how he got married and had babies. You want him to shut up, but you are too polite and just chuckle away like it's all funny, because the booze is free.
Seth is just amazing u couldn t stop laughing. give it a shot it is HILARIOUS!!

I feel like I need to preface this review w an honest statement that I love basically everything about Seth Meyers & always have. Even the word 'basically' is questionable - I can't think of anything I don't love about him. So much so that some nights I only watch Late Night for the first 15 or so minutes because I will never (& HAVE never) miss Seth's monologues & topical commentary/comedy skits/parodies on the off chance that I just don't have time to watch the whole show. I have never missed even one of his opening bits or a single 'weekend update' piece & even his early improv, the little bit that you might find if you search really well, is totally solid. I also think he was the second best writer ever on SNL, second only to Tina Fey - pretty good company, right?That being said, I was prepared to be at least slightly disappointed w his stand up. I've often thought about seeing him live but it's somewhat rare & usually nowhere near where I live. Plus, honestly, I get to enjoy him 5 nights a week (ok, that 'hinted suggestion' is a bit over the top, but it's another reason I love Seth - anyone who looks that good & is also that funny is just so lovable). So for what it's worth, I thoroughly enjoyed a fantastic hour watching one of my absolute favorite humans do some of the best stand up I've seen. Something about him is so entirely entertaining & witty, yet so easily relatable. Because of his relationship w his family (who DOESN'T love Larry, Hilary & Josh?), his undeniable respect for his wife Alexi & obvious love for his boys, I just can't imagine anyone not liking him. That's part of what's so great about this special - It's just 'Seth being Seth', but instead of monologues or lead ins & punchlines you get solid stand up. Also, admittedly, it's kind of fun to hear him drop a few F-bombs without being 'bleeped'. I'm not saying this is for everyone, some people may not like Seth (how that's possible I don't know, but to each his/her own, I suppose) - but if you like Late Night w Seth Meyers, if you liked him on SNL & you find him funny in general you will undoubtedly thoroughly enjoy this Netflix special. As I said, I was prepared to be disappointed because the bar was set so high (my own doing, but I'll blame him for being SO off the charts talented) but I was anything but disappointed. This is just GREAT stand up.That being said, it's not my absolute FAVORITE standup show ever - people who JUST do stand up are often SO well prepared, have perfect timing & truly have their craft down pat, but it is definitely fantastic stand up & given all his other talents, I was surprised to see that he is simply so very good at stand up.Check this out people, you won't be disappointed. Seth is a class act, a humorist at heart & just a good guy w a great sense of humor - watch it, you'll have at least one good hour that day.

I've always loved Seth and this special was the icing on the cake. It's done in his own personal style which I think works in this type of setting since he's very relaxed and conversational. And there were the funny little extras like his Skip button and the bit with his wife. Loved it.

I've been watching a lot of stand-up specials lately on Netflix and this was one of the funniest ones I've watched! I haven't actually laughed out loud at stand-up as much as I did with this one in a long time. His delivery is great.
President Trump bashing and a baby born in the lobby of a fancy building in New York. That's all it is. Don't bother wasting your time.

The only way I can justify why a great comedian like him would do this is if he tried to compensate for getting caught cheating by vouching that if wifey won't leave and take the kids, he'll write a whole special dedicated to her.Not the best comedy material, but it makes for great ideas on how to avoid divorce.
This was one of the best stand ups I've this year. Witty, well written, and poised for each delivery. I really enjoyed this. Show me more!!

I like Seth as a late night host, but this performance is embarrassingly bad. He starts off with jokes about Jewish people and a marriage-obsessed girlfriend... Um, what year is this? Oh right, it's 2019, and this stuff isn't funny.He comes across as just another privileged white (but uh, rest assured, non-Jewish and not such a feminist!) guy who thinks that he's hilarious and has a hard life. Really, Seth? Yeesh.

Seth Meyers is the funniest comedian Netflix has ever recorded and we are only half way through his show! We have laughed non-stop. I literally paused the show to write a review. We almost never comment on anything we rate, but this guy is absolutely freakin' funny!

I didn't used to like Seth. I didn't dislike him but, nothing. He's been growing on me slowly the last couple years as a late night host. This special put him into my current favourites. Solid laughs all the way through out loud here by myself. So happy you didn't make it all about politics, and it was all funny.

I am a big fan of Seth's work and this standup special is no different. The writing is really smart and well thought out and his delivery is perfect as always. I suggest everyone to watch this to have a good time because it is the kind of show which everyone can find something they relate to! I hope he does more stabdup specials in the future

This is what happens when you work on TV that long. Everything is calculated down to a nanosecond. The looks, the walks, the jokes, the time in between...everything perfectly timed. A performance right out of a script in which obviously a whole team of TV pros has put together.

I thought maybe there's a chance this could be funny. He had some good bits on the news desk with the other SNL talent. But holy crap, listen to the first few minutes and he's already trying to remind us of his SNL days. So lame. Not to mention the partisan politics. No thanks.

I didn't care much for Seth meyers before this and just put it on for something to watch. I was laughing from the start, seths standup style is nothing like his rigid persona on Late Night. He reminded me a bit of John mulaney at points

Seth is a funny observational comic. I enjoyed seeing him out from behind a desk, but I think he could have been just as funny without resorting to the F-bombs dropped throughout the routine.I had a hard time watching it due to the camera work.If I could talk to the director personally, I would slap him for his choice of incredibly loose camera shots.It seemed that two of the cameras were below stage level, and the operators had no clue how to properly frame a shot. Way too much headroom and "empty space". The "Rule of Thirds" does NOT apply in television.

I'd like to give it a higher rating but I was continually distracted by the poor framing of the close up shots. It seems like none of the CU camera operators understand appropriate head room and talk space. I understand the occasional want or need to be creative here or there but to give consistently improper framing on your subject is a huge distraction for the entire piece. I kept finding myself leaning to somehow center-up and tilt up the shots. Were there monitors used in the live shoot? I can't see a director saying that's exactly how it should look. Even when the occasional shot that looks good and is using exaggerated head room or framing, now looks forced because it wasn't used as a unique statement.
I missed Seth's standup and was glad to hear that he was putting out a new special.

It's like spending an evening with an old annoying friend. Some of it was OK, but all around it was bland. I think I may had smiled once or twice. The political jokes are annoying, typical of this type of comedian. His talent is not even close to the likes of Chappelle, Burr and Gaffigan.

An excellent performance, black comedian & mainly black audience, I expected a black oriented show. He rose above that and delivered an excellent, unbiased, funny take on events that often divide people. At times putting black people before a mirror, the audience loved him and I admire him for his balanced view on those events.

Only 9 stars because there's a bit too much profanity for my taste, but rest assured every bit is poignant and hilarious. Where so many are quick to blame everyone else, he reminds us that we're all partly responsible for the tragedies in life. Definitely a must watch, in my opinion. I hope he releases more specials in the future, because I'd really like to see where he goes next!

It's not everyday that a bright comedian shine! and the day Deray Davis went on stage to do his Netflix special, was sure not one of them.Deray is using the old card of being a black man in America to bring his old hacky material, that we all heard before. His show is like seeing a big intimidating black man trying to impersonate Eddie Murphy raw just with out the charisma, the talent or the fun feel. being proud that black man are natural in stealing, Deray scrap the bottom of the barrel for bringing cheap laughs to the table. in his eyes you can see he is not a guy that liked to be made fun of but he is taking it for the fame...As long as the super liberal in Netflix keep putting diversity first before talent, expect more horseshit stand up shows to come to us in the future, in the meantime do yourself a favor and skip this one...

His impression of Terrence Howard lands. Because it is personal. Otherwise he does not seem comfortable. He is out of his comfort zone. He is an actor, not a comedian. He acts like he is a comedian but he is not a comedian. He doesn't know what is funny. An annoying performance using scare tactics, saying the N* word every other sentence.

This stand-up set is smart, genuinely funny, and emotionally educational. DeRay Davis presents his humor and his opinions on current events and how they effect America (and even what else could be done) without an offended attitude. Truly, truly funny, and touching and honest at the same time. DeRay is a class act, celebrating where he's from, embracing where he is, and welcoming anyone who will listen to join him in search of possibilities. He actually succeeds in building bridges where the fear of racism and violence has left so many people in our culture frozen and unsure of what to think or say (Including myself, a white woman from an upper middle class upbringing, who's never lived in a place like Uptown Chicago) Yes... all this, I got from laughing at a man yelling about Harambe and mass shootings. The man knows what he's doing, and he's very good at it. Bravo, Netflix. Bravo, DeRay. If you dislike profanity, be warned there's plenty of it. But watch it anyway, if you can.

I didn't know who Joe Rogan was prior to finding "Triggered" on Netflix by browsing the stand-up comedy collection.I decided to give it a chance based on the short synopsis that was given. But it turned out that Joe Rogan's particular style of comedy and his jokes were not really suitable with what I liked, and I wasn't particularly entertained or impressed with what I saw here.Joe Rogan did have some good jokes here and there, but they were just far in between for my liking.I enjoyed the part with the sleeping impressions, when he was lurched on the chair, and that was my favorite part of the entire show.I can't claim to have been spurred on to seek out more of his shows of he has any though.

This was my third stand-up comedy that I watched from Joe Rogan and again I enjoyed it really much. He never fails to deliver. I agree it's most of the time stoner humor but that works fine with me. His humor is sometimes so recognizable for people that enjoy being high, it makes the experience even better. Joe Rogan is very vocal, almost shouting at times, very energetic and spastic on scene, so maybe not everyone's cup of tea. I like how he brings his jokes, they're well thought of, not obvious jokes but jokes only a stoner could come up with. Looking forward to his next show.

Joe Rogan is a special kind of stand-up comedian. Many try to copy the work of others, steal jokes and emulate a greater performer, but with Joe you can instantly tell he's just being himself, carrying out his own brand of wacky, almost eccentric comedy and it's a joy to watch on screen. He takes you on an adventure with his unusual outlook on subjects and questions what would happen in insane situations, all while making you burst with laughter. I've watched Joe for 15+ years, First his early days in the UFC, then his great stand-up routines and latterly in his wonderful Joe Rogan Podcast, but this has to be one of the best performances the man has ever put on.Overall one of the most impressive comedy specials I've seen and Joes unique brand of stand up is a wonder to witness. Incredibly funny, informative, opinionated and all this while taking you on a wild journey through the mind of a comedic madman, what more could you ask for.
If you like Joe's style of comedy, you'll enjoy the hell out of this.
This special had me laughing out loud. Great stuff, Joe. Very impressed.

What Joe Rogan did here was very, very brave.Joe Rogan opens every joke with laying out a verbal minefield for himself. Every time he starts a new joke I find myself saying "uh-oh" out loud, and by the end of every joke he has successfully managed to maneuver out of the minefield with humor and a valid point.I do myself strongly agree with him on some points and others not so much, but when i see past his showmanship i can see that there is a strong case behind his opinions.This made me laugh very much, but i'm not giving it a 10/10 purely because of the jokes. This routine is admirable because he dared discuss some of the most touchy subjects, in the most uncompromising way, in front of a large audience. 10/10 for bravery.

Because he absolutely killed this!I watch a lot of Joe Rogan's podcast and I watch a lot of UFC in which Joe Rogan is a legendary voice so I might be biased in ways, but I happen to share a lot of Joe Rogan's beliefs and point of views so even though he does portray a bit more macho douche in this show than what he usually does on his podcast, the way he is able to deliver his thoughts on society is on a level only few have been able to do.Easily the funniest show I have seen for years and easily the most hid- in-plain-sight intelligent one.The Bruce Jenner bit was just a new level of comedy.

Carlin comes back to New York in this 1992 comedy special and I actually liked it. This time, anger comes into him like never before and it fuels his comedy as he rants about the Persian Gulf War/Penises, Universal moments we share, The planet and environment, flying on the airplanes and the best part, Golf Courses for the homeless. Terrific entertainment with a added incentive: comes to Madison Square Garden to perform and makes the crowd rolling. Excellent, for Carlin fans. Best line: "What about those passengers traveling with large children? Suppose you have a 2 year old with a pertuitary disorder, you know a 6ft infant with an oversized head?" A++

If George Carlin has been known to use outrage and combine it with a razor-sharp wit to express his comedy, and if in his previous outing: DOING IT AGAIN, he was his usual manic, curmudgeonly self, JAMMIN' IN NEW YORK finds him just this shy of pure rage.It comes to no surprise to anyone who has seen Carlin on stage that he isn't one to shy away from telling it like it is for better or for worse. He begins his routine by immediately going political: about the Persian Gulf War, he says, "It's first war we've had that was on every news channel, plus cable. We like war because we're a war-like people (...) We're good at it. And it's a good thing we are, we're not very good at anything else anymore!" With this he begins his attack on how we as a nation can bomb other countries, especially "brown people" (except Germans, and only because they were trying to 'cut in on our action.'). He talks about being his own person, someone who thinks for himself, and about how war is about "prick-waving" and nothing else. And seeing it today as yesterday it makes sense: all he's pointing the finger at is on the general situation and where we're headed, and no one is better than he in making war as a concept a sexual thing and an issue of manhood.But he soon gets the political stuff out of the way, and goes into dissertations on embarrassing situations -- the trivial things we go through -- which are flat-out funny. No one better than Carlin to talk about how when there are times when you're coming up the stairs and think there is one extra step, or when you've woken up and not known which day it was. And of course, his forte: language, and our misuse or over use of it for things that don't need such technicality. Who better than he to talk about the minutiae of airplane instructions? Carlin, with his wonderful language and powerful wit, makes it happen. Often, it's funny, sometimes, a little cringe-inducing, but give me someone who does not like his humor and his incursions into the darker side of humanity and I will give you a liar. What is comedy, than a reflection of people's foibles and human tragedy?

George Carlin has only become more angry and bitter, making his comedy all the more funny. It also makes his comments on humanity, such as the state of the earth, all the more insightful and cutting. You can hear a pin drop during some of this show, people are not sure if it is safe to laugh. The best comedians can do this. The heavy war and earth stuff is counterweighted with lighter fare such as the stupidity of airline safety speeches. The golf course jokes are somewhere in between. Take this and Robin Williams joke about drunk Scotts creating golf to truly revel in the inanity of the most frustratingly boring sport ever imagined. George Carlin isn't for everyone, the old structure loving will be unpleased, but he is an intelligent man who is one of the most consistently amusing and relevant comics in the mainstream.

George Carlin has been talking about the way Americans act, talk, what should be taken out, and why are we sensitive. In Jammin in New York, he goes all out in a way I had never seen him. I had seen his special on HBO in January of 2002, which I got to say made me laugh more than anybody on the planet. Some of the lines like: somebody got f*ck in the ass! BLTPT! BLTPT! made me laugh my ass off. I only wish Sam Kinison were alive to see itFrom the specials i have seen George Carlin in, Jammin in New York is the best one
A successful comedian has good determinations, but I think he exaggerates some topics.

Truth be told, I don't watch George Carlin in order that I might succumb to a few chortles, but because I've always admired this man's incisive and forthright social commentary, which was usually spot-on. This guy knew how to tell it like it is. It is what made this particular stand-up comedian so unique. GC was not just about making his audience laugh. Any personified whoopee cushion atop a stage can do that. Carlin has been dubbed the thinking man's comic, and rightly so.I was curious to see how much of Carlin's material in JAMMIN' IN NEW YORK has stood the test of time and so re-viewed it in order to find that out. Much to my surprise, very little of it is outdated. About the only talk that is is the stuff about war in the Persian Gulf. This was one of his earlier live events, back when men wore pleated pants and ponytails. The latter happens to be a pet peeve of mine, but I digress.In the news of late, in certain parts of the globe, is this politicized clampdown on -- forget political graft, deceit, and corruption for a moment -- plastic of all things, which brings to mind one of the monologues contained here, titled "The Planet Is Fine." Very timely, this.Carlin also goes on about syntax and the hairsplitting of terminology as it applies to air travel, and as one who chooses to occasionally ignore conventional grammar himself for common sense, this bit was both identifiable and much appreciated.Superfluous wording. Ah, yes. Carlin notes how some people prefer to use highfalutin terms in order to make something sound more important than it actually is. Like the other week when I passed by a "hydration station" (i.e. water cooler). A mouth-watering term to any language-loving enunciator, but needlessly uppity-sounding to say the least.There is some constructive criticizing of the government, which is what democratic dissent is all about. The part about how those in power often seek to divide the people is something very few comics would go into, but Carlin does. He also has some unflattering things to say about environmentalists.Not every joke or observation goes over well. At least not with me. As one who likes to golf, I found Carlin's derisive remarks in regard to this particular pastime way off the mark. But considering we're both into free speech, I would rather he be free to voice erroneous and unfunny comments from time to time than be censored.Incidentally, I think Carlin's incorrect when he says that the term pre-recorded is a redundancy. This HBO special, for instance, was recorded in real time whereas, say, episodes of televised sitcoms are usually recorded beforehand, to be aired at a later date -- that is to say, they are pre-recorded. Getting analytical here, I know. Just saying.Overall, JAMMIN' IN NEW YORK is quite groovy and for the most part remarkably dateless. I can do without all the observational humor and there is some of that here as well. Carlin is at his best whenever he's on a riff or a rant and the least interesting when he resorts to body English and the making of funny faces. But I suppose some in the audience who are only amused by slapstick-like fare would find this entertaining and such ones are not left out from enjoying the show. Bravo!

First time I've watched a stand-up comedy from Greg Davies. I enjoyed it, had a good time. Greg Davies as a stand-up comedian has the talent and the charisma to make you laugh and to keep you interested until the end. His not afraid of laughing with himself, physically or with things he has done. Well at least if they are true, but that's not important, it was just funny. Jokes about his mother and father, about himself or others, it all made this show an enjoyable act to watch. I wouldn't say he's my favorite stand-up comedian, that's Jim Jefferies at this moment, but I will for sure look out and search for more of his stand-up comedies. If they are all like this one I will have more pleasant nights.
5/23/18. He was funny and witty and worth catching at least once. It's nice to see a comic who is comfortable in his own skin.

Watched this with a couple friends. Not so much as a chuckle passed anyone's lips. The guy's not funny. How he got into comedy I can only guess. Maybe those parents of his did the usual parent thing and kept telling how funny he was and that he should do standup...

I'm a fan of Greg Davies from Cuckoo and thought I would enjoy this, but I didn't. Too many rude jokes and making fun of his parents or people he has met in his life. Long, unfunny annecdotes which I can't really believe are true. I won't be watching more of his shows.

Several good belly laughs which I guess I needed. Thanks Greg. I am now a fan.Yeah he made me laugh -- I think that's the definition of a good standup comic.(FYI: I'd never seen any of his routines nor watched him in any tv shows, etc)The ending of You Magnificent Beast was unexpected, beautiful AND hilarious.
He needs better material. Just not funny. amazing what you can away with. trivial and not funny. He's a good comedy actor and he gives everything in this but the jokes are dire. Couldn't chuckle.

I signed up here because I could not believe the negative reviews!!! He is beyond talented and gives so much joy!!! He brings humour into everything we do! Thank you, Greg Davies! He is at his best when he jokes about his mother or anything to do with his family. Magnificent storyteller!

Greg Davies is the epitome of British humour, if you can't accept this as an exponentially hilarious stand-up, then I can't accept you as a Brit- or someone with a sense of humour-. This may seem extreme, but this stand up is everything that is right with the world and Greg Davies is a magnificent man and tremendous comic. You are allowed your opinions BUT NEITHER ME OR GREG ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE RESULT OF LEAVING A BAD REVIEW! You have been informed. Good day squire.

This stand up show was filmed at the Orpheum Theater in Minneapolis in 2016. Almost all of the reviewers before me here thought Jeff Foxworthy was funny and Larry the Cable Guy wasn't. I thought both did a pretty decent job even if I've seen them in better performances before. My wife, who didn't know either of these comics, was shocked a bit by Larry in the audience reacting poorly to one of Jeff's bits; I had to tell her he was in on the joke. Foxworthy expounded on the idea that facts of life can't be googled and that kidney stones are worse than having a baby. Larry touched on Wal-Mart, a favorite topic, along with garage sales and getting older. Unlike almost all the other comics appearing in specials like this today, these two guys do it without the use of four letter words, keeping it in the realm of family entertainment. My only let down with this show was they didn't do a few minutes together bantering back and forth to wind things up.

I agree that Jeff's segment was by far the better of the 2. However, this was the first time he went 'low' - stooped to poop and sexual humor. He was funny, because - well - he's still Foxworthy, but not nearly as funny as in any of his previous specials. However Larry had so few chuckles that the rating would have been much lower had Jeff not been on the stage (but wait for the segment starting with the Grocery store and Grandpa jokes - from that point on, he's funny).

If this had been just a Jeff Foxworthy comedy special, I would have given this show a 9/10 rating. Jeff Foxworthy is the first one to come out and he does the first half of the show. His material was fresh and very funny. I thoroughly enjoyed watching him.Then, Jeff Foxworthy leaves the stage and Larry the Cable Guy comes out. The very first thing he starts off with is a bit on Git-R-Done. I think I mildly chuckled only twice during his whole routine. I was very disappointed and kept wishing that the show had either already ended when Jeff Foxworthy was done or that Jeff would come back out and finish the show. At one point during Larry the Cable Guy's routine, they panned out to the audience and showed Jeff Foxworthy sitting there. He was not laughing. That got me wondering if he actually thinks that Larry the Cable Guy is funny. I know I sure didn't find him to be very amusing.My recommendation is that you watch the show up until the point where Jeff Foxorthy's routine is done. Then stop watching. It is not worth your time. I almost stopped watching after a few minutes into Larry the Cable Guy's routine, but I kept waiting and hoping that it would get better. It didn't.

I loved when Jeff did the bit about kidney stones, because I relate to pain and getting older, and I think he really gets his target audience. When Jeff joked about the dog poop, it reminded me of times that I stepped in poop and I joked about it with my friend, whose name is Nader. This special reminds me of a car wreck I had last year that left me crippled because I was trapped inside for about an hour and that's how long the special is. I didn't like Larry too much, because I feel like he has started recycling jokes since he did those heartburn commercials. The best way to watch this is to look your friend Nader in the eyes and both of you try not to laugh.

Once Jeff finishes his bit turn it off you'll thank me later. Larry the Cable Guy was off his game in this one throwing out a line of random nonsense jokes. The bit on global warming was terrible and troubling. He had no clue what he was talking about and gave the uneducated American explanation. This wasn't even The worst part. The good new Jeff Foxworthy was on his game and you'll have a number of good laughs. It was a classic Foxworthy performance. You'll have to check out. As for Larry I was shocked because usually his routines are at a minimum decent I think i only laughed once during his whole 30 mins. Still a fan but no where near what I was used to.
Very entertaining had my gut hurting from laughing so hard. But what made it even funnier is at 9:28-9:31 Larry actually eye rolls at Jeff's joke.

I thoroughly enjoy the stand-up comedy shows from Jo Koy, and I am glad to see that he still has his edge with this 2019 performance in "Jo Koy: Comin' in Hot".If you aren't already familiar with the stand-up acts of Jo Koy from previous shows, then I can warmly recommend that you take the time to get familiar with his performances and watch the shows, because this guy is hilarious. Not only is he funny, but he also has a great on stage performance and he has some nice things to talk about in his shows.I enjoy how he always includes his mother and the Filipinos in his stand-up shows. And when he brought in more Asian types in "Jo Koy: Comin' in Hot" it was just brilliant, and he nailed their mannerisms and ways of talking so well."Jo Koy: Comin' in Hot" was enjoyable from start to end, and is very enjoyable even if you are not already familiar with this stand-up comedian guy.Watch it. Just watch it...

I saw at one of Jo Koy's older comedy specials a couple of months ago on Netflix and it didn't impress me. In fact, I just watched it a couple of minutes then stopped and didn't finish it.I saw some of his new acts recently though and they were good, that's why I decided to watch his latest one, and I have to say that he definitely has upped his game, this special is very funny from start to finish.Jo Koy makes fun of Hawaiian customs, Asian/Latin/Black stereotypes, his mom, Filipino customs, etc. and towards the end of his act, Sex Organs. Some people might find some of his material to be offensive, but I guess that is one reason that makes it so funny.A Must Watch for me, one of the really funny Stand Up Comedy Specials on Netfllix.
This guy is all hat, no cattle. The audience seems artificially hyped to get the viewers interested. He never says anything funny. I couldn't watch the whole thing, what a mess.
I had some expectations, but in the end I enjoyed every moment. Regardless of some IMDB reviews he is a great comedian. I enjoyed adding to where others have never gone before.

This was the worst stand up I've seen from Jo. I literally left the room while my wife finished up.When a comedian spends the bulk of his routine making fun of races and talking about his dick size, you know it's out of desperation and that's exactly what this seemed like to me. Desperate for material. He didn't have anymore jokes about his mom so he went for the lowest common denominators. Really disappointed.
I cannot stop watching it lol I highly recommend it. And his Seattle show too

Breaking is when a performer breaks character and in Jokoy's case he just kept laughing and giggling throughout jokes. Jokes were alright but would've been more impactful if (a) the crowd didn't just laugh blindly at everything, every word every phrase, even a lead-in when there's not even a pubchline and (b) it Jokoy's delivery was sharper, like Ali Wong...

JoKoy does great in this special. I'm not a JoKoy fan, but if there's a new special on Netflix, I'm going to check it out. Jo talks alot about his family, his mother and father. He jokes about how they acted while he was growing up, like their mannerisms, customs, etc.. He touches on cultural differences, and him being a father. Overall the jokes connect, they're very funny, I found myself laughing out loud which I rarely do even if something is funny. Nothing ground breaking, very relatable comedy. It would be a good watch with friends around.

I discovered jo koy during pandemic, that's where I discovered how great stand up comedy is. Up to now I follow him.For those haters out there, we don't believe your hate and fake comments. The people have spoken we love jo koy and we can relate. Tell those comments to sold out arenas and Steven Spielberg liking this special.
Can this guy write any new jokes? This was a snooze-fest
I, too, chuckled like three times. And I also missed out on some material because I don't speak Spanish.
I laughed really hard, it was funny, good way to spend an hour

It's helpful to appreciate & be familiar with the Latinx culture - I loved the George Lopez show & there is familiar humor in this stand up because of his style. George makes fun of some very real cultural nuances & he does it right. It's a yes for me!

It's the same old, same old on this one. Basically, it's like listening to my drunk uncle tell stories. First you take something normal like getting milk out of the fridge, throw in an east-Los accent, use a couple of curse words and Spanish slang words and voila! You have the George Lopez recipe for filling an hour's worth of material. Got about 30 minutes and had to bail.
Lots of political talk which is obviously funny until he keeps going on and on about it. 2/3 is him speaking in Spanish. Understand, that is his way but not that great.

People are acting like it's 2021. And need to chill for a bit and enjoy the jokes as for it being just jokes and loosen up a bit and go back to the 90s mentality where we don't criticize so much where we take it to a "Karen" level lol, if you don't like don't watch. simple but I watched and I loved it. his mind is a wholesome level 🔥
